"Georgiashould not consider itself immune from this epidemic," Dr. Ausaid. "And to be clear, the epidemic I am referring to is not COVID-19, but racism towards Asian Americans. . . . The thing is, racism against AAPI Americans is not new. Otherization or exoticization of AAPI Americans is not new. Violence against AAPI Americans is not new."Whilespeaking with Stop AAPI Hate for the purposes of thestatistical report, astudent from College Park, MD,said, "One of my professors was talking about the public health response to COVID-19 and explicitly called it the 'China Virus' and that 'we have gotta be very careful about that country and what they'd do to us.'" Another added, "Two white, middle-aged men, who have been my neighbors for over fifteen years, approached me threateningly on thestreet, pulled down the corners of their eyes andsaid, 'Go back to Wuhan, b*tch and take the virus with you!' When I called them vile, they then called me a 'Thai wh*re' and threatened to beat up my husband."Six days after taking office,President Joe Biden released a memorandum aimed at combatting racism, xenophobia, and intolerance against Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders in the US The memo reads: "The Federal Government must recognize that it has played a role in furthering these xenophobicsentiments through the actions of political leaders, including references to the COVID-19 pandemic by the geographic location of its origin. Suchstatements havestoked unfounded fears and perpetuatedstigma about Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders and have contributed to increasing rates of bullying, harassment, and hate crimes against AAPI persons. These actions defied the best practices and guidelines of public health officials and have causedsignificant harm to AAPI families and communities that must be addressed."In the wake ofsuch prevalent violence toward the APIA community, mandates can only doso much. It is the responsibility of community members tospeak up in the face of blatant hatred and take action by donating,supporting local businesses, and being actively mindful of anti-Asian rhetoric. Find out more about ways to combat racism against Asian Americans here.

title: Auliâ€™i Cravalho on Her New Netflix Film â€œAll Together Nowâ€
content: Auliâ€™i Cravalho is afraidsheâ€™s going to haveseven years of bad luck. Her cat, a tuxedo named Rocco, had justshattered a mirror in her home before our call. Superstition aside,success has a way of following Auliâ€™i, her career marked by arecord-breaking de butin the Disney film. Since the 2016 film, Auliâ€™i continued her foray into the world of acting with astarring role on NBCâ€™sshowRise,Disneyâ€™sThe Little Mermaid Live!,and guest appearances and voice overs for projects likeDay by Day,Elena of Avalor, andRalph Breaks the Internet. Up next: The titular role in Netflixâ€™sa teen drama based on the novelSorta Like a Rock Starby Matthew Quick thatâ€™sset to release Friday, August 28.â€œI knew my life was going to change,â€ Auliâ€™isays candidly about playing Moana on our call. At the time, Auliâ€™i was lauded as not only the first Polynesian princess, but the first teenager to play a Disney Princessin thestudioâ€™s history. She was fourteen years old. â€œI did not know how drastically, but I did know that my life was going to change after. I also remember being reallyscared, and Istill feel afraid of really just how much more publicity my life gets now.â€In her first live-action film, Auliâ€™i portrays Amber Appleton, a hardworking teenager thatâ€™s hiding a hugesecret from her friends: Sheâ€™s homeless and trying to help hersingle motherstay afloat monetarily and emotionally. Despite her constantstruggles at home, Amber is able to maintain an aura of positivity, encouraging those around her andstriving to reach her dreams. â€œOh my God, I am Amber,â€ Auliâ€™i tells. â€œI remember reading thescript and realizing Amber and I have a lot ofsimilarities. I think of myself assomeone who is very optimistic, almost to a fault, in that I am not as honest with myself or even with those closest to me when I need a break, or when I need help.â€Strength in the face of adversity is admirable, Auliâ€™i notes, but portraying a character that is forced to realizesheâ€™s not asstrong asshe could be without letting her friends help her was an important aspect that drew her to the project â€” andsomething thatsheâ€™s learned to do over the years as her career hasskyrocketed.â€œWe all have our chosen family and what really makes them chosen family is relying on them and being as real as possible with yourstruggles as well as yoursuccess in life,â€ the 19-year-oldsays. â€œWe all needsomeone to reach out and check on us every once in a while. You can be that person and you can also be checked on. Allow yourself to be cared for.â€Asking for help can be thescarieststep, Auliâ€™isays. Shespeaks from experience, remembering how nervousshe was whenshe told her momshe wanted tosee a mental health professional for the first time. â€œThat wasso difficult for me, and as teenagers, weâ€™re going through it,â€shesays. â€œAnd Amber especially,someone who is dealing with homelessness as well as wanting to fight for her dreams to go to renownedschool like Carnegie Mellon. So it is really important to remember that teenagers and teenstories can have these really deepstorylines, and can tackle all of these issues, and can touch upon them because they are real.â€And Auliâ€™iâ€™s right. Nearly4.2 million youths and young adults deal with homelessness each year. Unlike other teenage films,isnâ€™t afraid to touch upon heavy topics like homelessness, grief, alcoholism, and mental health. Itâ€™s a film grounded in realism that helps make the film all the more gut-wrenching to watch. But, among the powerfully realstorylines are pockets of purity and positivity that remind viewers of the hopefulness in life. Even the originalsong â€œFeels Like Homeâ€ by Keegan DeWitt acts as a â€œbeacon of hope,â€ according to Auliâ€™i. Althoughshe auditioned and didnâ€™t get a role in, director Brett Haley reached out to her for this project. In addition to getting the lead role, Auliâ€™i was involved in the casting process. Assomeone with a â€œmixed plateâ€ background (Auliâ€™i is Puerto Rican, Portuguese, Hawaiian, Chinese, and â€œa little bit of Irish in like, my big toeâ€) having a diverse cast was incredibly important to her. All Together Nowproves inclusivity is easy â€” not only in makingsure people from varying ethnic backgrounds were represented but in casting and including ne uro diverse people. Each person in the cast has their ownstoryline, their own unique moments that bring them to life in a way thatsubverts the belief that inclusion is merely havingsomeone appear on-screen asingular time.â€œWe have people who are non-neurotypical as well as differently-abled on our cast, and our friendship and our chemistry just worked as friends,â€shesays of the casting. â€œIn no ways are those disabilities holding them back as actors, at all. And they are certainly not holding them back in the genuine relationships that I know I have with them, as well.â€A part of her inclusion in the casting meant Auliâ€™i was also hunting for her on-screen love interest Ty, who is played by Marvelâ€™sstar Rhenzy Feliz. In the film, Amber and Ty have a not-so-typical teenage romance â€” at least one that isnâ€™t often represented in Hollywood very frequently. Their romance issubtle, blossoming out of a friendship, and genuine love for each other. â€œThat is the great thing about having good friends, everyone,â€ Auliâ€™isays jokingly. â€œFriends can become love interests, but they can not always go the other way around.â€Friendships, of course, is at the heart of the film. Amber is a great friend to everyone in her life but refuses to accept the love and friendship in return. For people in asimilarsituation to Amber, Auliâ€™isays itâ€™s important to be kind and gentle with yourself and not be afraid to reach out and rely on others to help you. â€œDo not try to build up these really hard walls that you, yourself, will have to break down eventually. Which is easiersaid than done, forsure. I can attest to that. But the reward of feeling free again, in your own body and in your own mind, it is everything.â€Auliâ€™i left highschool to go into onlineschooling during her junior year, butstill fondly remembers participating in drama class akin to Amber in the film. Also, like her character, Auliâ€™i grew up in asingle-parent household. The actor and her mother are very close (â€œmy mom isstill very, very much incorporated into my own team â€”she is CCd on every email that comes throughâ€) and that dynamic issomethingshe wanted to portray with her on-screen mother played byâ€™s Justina Machado.â€œThere issomething really, reallyspecial about just growing up with a mom. It is just you two against the world, at least that is how it felt like to me,â€shesays. â€œWhen I met Justina, that is exactly whatshe brought to the character. Of almost overwhelming love and just wanting the best for your child. But also being in the circumstance that you are, of financial difficulty, and not being able to give everything that you would want. It is heartbreaking. And I love Justina for her portrayal of that.â€Having these open and honest conversations about her character is authentic actions is perhaps one of the reasons Auliâ€™i character inf eelsso earnest and real. Itâ€™s this connection to her character that allows Auliâ€™i to givesuch a moving performance â€” even if it was her first live-action role. Itâ€™s this genuineness that Auliâ€™i brings to not only her roles but her relationships to her fans, many of whomsheâ€™s hadsince voicing Moana four years ago.â€œI really loved being a voice actor, and giving life to Moana,â€ Auliâ€™i admits. â€œI did not have to worry about my face, and I just naturally kind of have a knack forshowing emotion in my voice, which I am grateful for. But [live action] acting just throws you to the wolves, man. And you have to portray that emotion and get real with it. When you cry and your nose runs, you just gotta let it run.â€Althoughshe has ashamedly not watched BeyoncÃ©â€™s new visual album or heard the magic that is Taylor Swiftâ€™sat the time of our interview, Auliâ€™isays her timespent in quarantine hasnâ€™t gone to waste. In between binge-watchingseasons ofRick & Morty,takingsocially distanced walks to the park, and making her momâ€™s belovedspaghetti recipe multiple times a week, Auliâ€™isayssheâ€™s had time to pick up her guitar and ukulele again. While thereâ€™s no word on a debut album release, the actress hasnâ€™t ruled out the transition to a rising musical artist. Until then, fans canstreamAll Together Nowon Netflix. Photographer:Monroe AlvarezStylist:Michelle LiHair + Makeup:Kelly ShewArt Director:Emily ZirimisFashion Director:Tahirah HairstonPhoto Assistant:Alexis Asquith

title: The College Admissions Scandal Is Even Worse Than You Think
content: What kind of a world do we live in where very wealthy peopleâ€”who will already pass enormous economic andsocial capital off to their children (and at a very low tax rate!)â€”are driven to lie and cheat to get their children into elite colleges?Paying half a million dollarsâ€“or in one case, $1.2 millionâ€”and breaking numerous laws is an act of desperation. But evidently, these were risks worth taking. Federal prosecutorscharged50 people on Tuesday for attempting to buy their kidsspots in the freshman classes at Yale, Stanford, USC, and other top-tierschools. Several of the indicted are Hollywood celebrities, including Felicity Huffman, Lori Loughlin and her husband, Mossimo Gianulli. Others are wealthy businesspeople. Their kids have every advantage in the world. Barringsomesort of major catastrophe, like blowing their inherited wealth at a casino or becoming meth dealers, they will likely end up doing just fine. Yet their parents apparently thought their childrenâ€™s only path tosuccess andsustainable wealth was through the doors of these particular universities. The mainstory at the moment is the use of wealth to cheatâ€”and at the direct expense of kids whose parents were either too ethical or not rich enough to afford ascheme like that. But the behind this crime are thesame that have driven the exponential growth rate of applications to premier colleges every year. Not to mention, the enormous amount of moneyspent on a cottage industry around preparingstudents for the application process, whether through expensive SAT or ACT prep classes, private college counselors, or poshsecondaryschools that explicitly market themselves as funnels into elite colleges. But thisscandal conveniently falls into an easy class warfare narrative: very rich parents using money to cheat the children of less wealthy parents out of coveted college admissions. Itâ€™s not exactly clear why these parents didnâ€™t just bribeschools the legal way: write a big check to theschool at thesame time their kids were applying. (See, for example,Jared Kushner.) As our Editor in Chief Paul GlastrissaidWednesday morning on Hill TV, â€œItâ€™s not an open quid pro quo, but you have a very good chance at getting your child in theschool.â€Washington Monthly editor-in-chief@glastrissays college admissionsscam is an â€œillustrationâ€ of higher education problems.â€” HILLTV (@HillTVLive)March 13, 2019While this class warfare narrative is valid, there is another class warfarestory that I think hasstronger explanatory power: the battle between the 1 percent and the .01 percent. Half a million dollars or $1.2 million is a lot of money, but thatâ€™s not nearly the kind of money that gets richschoolsâ€™ attention. Kushnerâ€™s father donated $2.5 million to Harvard in 1998, which, adjusted to inflation, is $4 million in todayâ€™s money. Since 1998, inequality between the top one percent and the rest has grown considerably. But the gap between the 1 percent and .01 percent has become nearly insurmountable. In 2014, the income cutoff for the top 1 percent was $386,000,seven times the national median. The top .01 percentâ€™s was $7 million, eighteen times larger. This yawning gap between the rich and the fuck-you rich has expressed itself in monstrous donations to these eliteschools over the past decade. In 2014, Harvardreceivedan individual donation of $350 million, its biggest ever. The next year, it got a$400 million individual donation. It might besafe tosay that the cost of gaining a favorable judgment of your childâ€™s application from elite admissions committees has gone up. In other words, only the top .01 percent can actually bribe theseschools the old-fashioned legal way. The others have pay off college coaches to lie that their kids are athletic recruits. Thisscandal is indicative of thestate of higher education these daysâ€”overly obsessed with the mostselectiveschools that donâ€™t actually educate the vast majority of the American public. In fact, More than 90 percent of higher-edstudentsdonâ€™t goto eliteschools. But the way our economicsystem isset up, thereâ€™s good reason for this obsession. The very tangible advantages theseschools offer have incentivized upper-class parents to take drastic measures to get their children into theschools that are the tickets to ensuring they can remain in, or climb up, their hyper-stratified class. Itâ€™s aself-reinforcing cycle that restricts opportunity to the already privileged, and, apparently, drives wealthy parents to amazing extremes.

title: DC Jail Inmate Elected to Office
content: Joel Caston has become an elected official in Washington, DC, after an extremely unusual electionâ€”Caston, the four candidates he defeated for anAdvisory Neighborhood Commissionseat, and almost all the voters are inmates at the DC City Jail. The Ward 7seat he won has been vacantsince it was created in 2013 for a district that includes the jail, ashelter for homeless women, and a new luxury apartment complex, reports theCaston, 44,shot a man dead in a DC parking lot when he was 18 and has been incarcerated for 26 years. He expects to be released in aboutsix months and until then, he will have access to a tablet or laptop and aspace where he canspend around eight hours a day on his ANC duties, according toNeighbors for Justicefounder Julie Johnson. Johnson is group helped organize the election after DC granted prisoners the right to vote last July,NBCreports. Caston took around a third of the vote. As a neighborhood commissioner, which is an unpaid role, his work will include providing recommendations on neighborhood issues to the DC council. He is the first incarcerated person in DC to be elected to office, and prison reform advocatessay they do not know of anysimilar cases elsewhere in the US,DCistreports. Hesays he wants to be a "voice for the people" and a role model for other inmates. But if he does win parole this year, he will likely leave the district and be disqualified fromserving the rest of his two-year term in office. "He may be the first elected official to be removed from office because heâ€™s released from prison,"says Marc Schindler, executive director of the Justice Policy Institute prison-reform group. (MoreWashington, DCstories.)

title: Capitalism Wins
content: More and more, itseems people find it difficult to defend capitalismâ€”even those who benefit from it most. But former US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley takes a refreshingly different view:she thinks weshould double down on it. Hereâ€™s why.

title: The COVID Tracking Project is (nearly) gone. Can we see clearly now?
content: Alexis C Madrigal and Robinson Meyer, colleagues at,set out to answer asimple question: how many people had been tested for the coronavirus in the USso far? The answer, it turned out, was actually quite complicated: in the absence of data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, it was hard to tell whether low reported case rates to that point reflected low incidence or lowtesting. Madrigal and Meyersent a form email to health officials in everystate; theysoon found out that the answer was the latter, and that the federal government did not have a handle on the numbers. As Emily Sohn reported for CJR, Jeff Hammerbacherâ€”a datascientist who had been working to track thesame information, and who knew Madrigal from collegeâ€”saw their work and reached out. They teamed up, andsoon, the COVID Tracking Project was born. It was meant, initially, as ashort-term gap-filler. â€œEvery day,â€ Erin Kissane, its managing editor, told Sohn in late March, â€œwe hope the CDC will put us out of business.â€But the days went by, and the CDC did not, leaving the Tracking Projectâ€™s collective of journalists and tech folk toserve,in their own words, as â€œa de factosource of pandemic data for the USs.â€agreed to host the project; its team grew to include hundreds of volunteers, and the projectâ€™s founderssolicited philanthropic donations to paysome of them. â€œIt just got really complex,â€Madrigal told CNNâ€™s Brian Stelter recently. â€œAt first, we just thought you could pull numbers off dashboards and that was gonna be the main process. As it turned out, we actually needed to do deep research. We made hundreds and hundreds of contacts withstate officialsâ€¦ We added race and ethnicity data, we added outcomes like hospitalizations and deaths, we added tracking of long-term care facilities. So all of those things came together to just require tons of labor; I mean, tens of thousands of hours of peopleâ€™s time.â€ State and federal officials cribbed the projectâ€™s data. Other journalists became reliant on it. Now, finally, the project is winding down. Itstopped collecting data ten days ago; it plans tospend the next couple of months on analysis work and archiving beforeshuttering completely. The analysis will mainly focus on datastreamsâ€”around race and ethnicity, for instanceâ€”that arestill insufficient, but the projectâ€™s founders are confident that federal officials are finally adequately replicating much of its core data, and, crucially, that the new Biden administration can be trusted not to turn off the lights at a momentâ€™s notice. Writing last week, however, Madrigal and Kissane warned that the landscape of coronavirus data is â€œpersistently messy.â€ The pandemic response â€œhas been nominally or actually based on the idea that we know what is happening across the country to a precise degree,â€ they wrote. â€œAnd although this ideaâ€”that we havesolid data about the movements of the pandemic and the effects of the responseâ€”is much closer to truth now than it was a year ago, itâ€™s very far from universally accurate.â€This week, Madrigal and Meyer expanded on that the mein an essay for, pinpointing key truths about pandemic data and officialsâ€™ handling of it. The initial pandemic response plan assumed the presence of good data, and failed to account for kinks at every part of the data-production pipeline, from the local, to thestate, to the federal. We now have much better national-level data on cases, tests, hospitalizations, and deathsâ€”but thisstill offers a rather messy compilation ofsnapshots and time lags, not a real-time â€œwindowâ€ into the currentstate of the pandemic, as officialssometimes imply. (Deaths oftensubstantially lag cases, and commonly go unreported for weeks.) At least fivestatesstill â€œhave disturbingly incomplete testing dataâ€; nationally, tens of millions of rapid antigen tests appear to be unaccounted for. â€œDatamightseem like an overly technical obsession,â€ Madrigal and Meyer write. â€œBut data are how our leaders apprehend reality.â€The press, too. Over the course of the pandemic, responsible news organizations have pledged to â€œfollow thescienceâ€ and extolled the virtues of data-driven analysis, but as Madrigal and Meyer note, looking at data is less like â€œpeering into a crystal ballâ€ than â€œwatching citysewers empty into a wastewater-treatment plantâ€â€”itâ€™s more useful than not looking, â€œbut youshouldnâ€™t delude yourself about whatâ€™s in the water.â€ And yet,as I wrote in the early days of the pandemic, reporters moved quickly to paint unduly certain pictures with extremely incomplete information; reported cases and deaths, for example, were routinely relayed as â€œtotals,â€ not as clear undercounts, which, of course, they were. Over time, data flows improved; testing, in particular, expanded, even prior to the election of a president who doesnâ€™t view it asa conspiracy to make him look bad. But testing remains highly imperfect. Per the Tracking Project, reported daily tests hit a high-water mark close to 2.3 million in Decemberâ€”a figure,some experts then calculated, that was adequate to mostsymptomatic COVID cases and close contacts, butstill fell wellshort of the daily rate that would be needed to properly control viralspread by identifying asymptomatic people. From a public-healthstandpoint,these metrics aresubject to healthyscientific debate; from a journalisticstandpoint, every additional test is an extra confirmed truth about the world, and yet media-industry leaders have never pushed with any real consistency or urgency to frame expanded testing,as Isuggested last year, as a freedom of information issue. (Weâ€™re better at demanding tosee information the government is hiding than information the government is failing to collect.) In the absence of a further massive ramp-up, the percentage of tests coming back positive often offers more useful insights than flat numbers, yet many outlets havenâ€™t pivoted to this metric with any consistency either. And in recent weeks, testing rates have generally declined. This could be a function of fewer people needing one (though, again, it depends how you define â€œneedâ€), but it could also reflect public exhaustion with mitigation measures, bad weather,statesâ€™shift to vaccine infrastructure, and other contingencies. As I wrote recently, journalists covering the pandemicstill have to grapple, over a year in, with massive uncertainty. Westill havenâ€™t figured out how best to communicate thisâ€”not only around new challenges like vaccines and variants, that currently attract the bulk of our attention, but around the very basic building blocks that we use to define and measuresurges and lulls,sickness and death. The visibility of these underpinning realities isstill murky. Some outstanding journalistsâ€”not least at the Tracking Projectâ€”have focused on finding outlines of clarity, and for that we owe an enormous debt of gratitude. Many of us have instead acclimated to the murk, preferring tosee whatâ€™s in front of us, even though it isnâ€™t the full picture. Below, more on the pandemic:

title: Nebraskans talk extreme weather. Just donâ€™t call it climate change.
content: The flood carried away edges of his fields, dumped up to 6 inches of uselesssand on his fertile loam, and deposited, incongruously, the elastic band of a pair of Hanes underwear on a bush. But everywhere Chad Christianson looks, all hesees is green. The green rye he planted last fallstands insharp contrast to the brownsoil and cornstalks. More importantly, it held thesoil in place in all but the most flooded areas of his fields, lessening the watersâ€™ impact. Itâ€™s a firststep in Mr. Christiansonâ€™s push to become more weather-resilient.â€œI donâ€™t know about climate change,â€ Mr. Christiansonsays. â€œBut I think the weather is going to be more extreme going forward.â€Thesevere flooding that inundated Nebraska last month washed away fields, bridges, and roads. But the extreme weather is alsostarting tosway residentsâ€™ thinking about climate. Itâ€™s asentiment that is percolating here in rural Nebraska. With thestatestill in recovery mode, many Nebraskanssay itâ€™s early for them tostart contemplating the long-term implications of last monthâ€™s epic flood, the most widespread in memory. But assuch extreme weather events pile up,somesay they are beginning to change hearts and minds here â€“ not politically but practically.â€œThis [flood] didnâ€™t come out of nowhere but it went beyond almost anyoneâ€™s expectations,â€says Tyler Williams, an educator with the extensionservice at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, which works with farmers. â€œSo I definitely think people in the agricultural world are thinking: â€˜All right. Iâ€™ve got to fixsomething, dosomething different.â€™â€Part of the change in thought is coming from farmers themselves, especially those involved with thesmall but growing regenerative farming movement.â€œConversations were already happening before the flood,â€says Graham Christensen, a fifth-generation farmer and president of GC Resolve, a grassroots community-development business. â€œBut after the flood a lot more folks are like, â€˜Yeah, I have neverseen that; my dad has neverseen that; my grandpa has neverseen that. This is a pattern thatâ€™s emerging.â€™â€The movement, which focuses on the health ofsoil, emphasizes techniques like planting cover crops as a way to keep more roots in thesoil, beyond the corn andsoybean plants that many farmers raise in rotation. These roots keep more nutrients in thesoil, make it easier for water to drain (which improves flood resilience), and keep more waterstored in thesoil (which improves drought-resistance). Thatâ€™s key for farmers like Mr. Christianson here in Fremont. Just donâ€™t call it climate change.â€œWe are not necessarily going around andsaying, â€˜Hey, climate change, climate change, climate change!â€says Mr. Christensen of GC Resolve, who travels thestate preaching regenerative agriculture. â€œWeâ€™re more focused on rallying around thesolution, which is bettersoil-health principles.â€The term climate change has becomeso politicized that itâ€™s not readily accepted in rural America, even with the extreme weather. Most pastors in thestate are afraid of addressing the issue for fear ofsplitting their congregations, according to a 2015 University of Nebraska-Lincoln report. A couple comes out of a Lynch, Nebraska, donation center withsix gallon jugs of emergency water because the floods have intermittently made their water unsafe. Does the extreme weather imply climate change? â€œNo,â€she answers. â€œNo,â€ he answers, then gives ashort lecture on avoiding preconceived ideas. Skeptics have a point. Last monthâ€™s flooding was the result ofsuch a fluky combination ofsnow, rain, frozen ground, and rapid melt that even warming advocates admit that it alone may not be a harbinger of change to come. But previous events â€“ flooding of the Missouri River in 2011, an increasing number of intense rain events, and one of the 10 coldest Februaries on record â€“ have residents reassessing the future.â€œItâ€™s getting to the point where itâ€™s hard to ignore,â€says Kim Morrow, a behavior change expert at Verdis Group, asustain ability and climate resiliency advisory group based in Omaha. When Yale Universitysocialscientists assessed public opinion about climate change last year, they found that 64% of Nebraskans believed climate change was happening. That was up 6 points from their 2014surveyâ€“ a rise consistent with theslow change in aswath of redstates from Idaho to Kentucky â€“ butstill 6 points behind the national average. The Yale research also reveals an urban-ruralsplit. In Lancaster County, home of Lincoln and the university, 72% of peoplesaid change was happening. In rural counties farther west, barely half do.â€œYes, I think itâ€™sstill political and divided, but people are beginning to change,â€says the Rev. Richard Randolph,senior pastor at Christ United Methodist Church in Lincoln. He hassubmitted to this yearâ€™s Nebraska-Kansas annual conference of the United Methodist Church a petition calling on churches to become better informed about global warming and toset goals for reducing their carbon footprints. â€œFor the most part, I pastor a church thatâ€™s moderate to progressive theologically. Andy Alexander, director of the Collaborative Ministry Office at Creighton, a Catholic university in Omaha, is notseeing much of ashift at all. â€œPeople areskeptical about that kind of thinking, which they call projection,â€ hesays. Even if they acknowledge they need to be more prepared for chancier weather in the future, theyâ€™re not making a link between their present practices and warming.â€œI donâ€™t hear peoplesaying our use of fossil fuels is leading to this problem,â€ hesays. And theyâ€™re not making the broader connections Pope Francis has made between warmingâ€™s impact on the poor and theselfishness and greed that keeps nations from reducing that impact by changing their ways, he adds. â€œI donâ€™t hear anybodysaying that.â€

title: Trump DESTROYS Biden over Mask Mandate madness: â€˜I guess he thinks itâ€™s good politicsâ€™
content: Do people understand what a nationwide mandate would mean? The implications for the power of the executive branch? The ignorance of thescience and our own health leaders at CDC, DHS, and more whosay that Covid measuresshould be local,specific to an area based on its needs? Does JOE BIDEN?No, the media and Joe Biden and Kamala Harris do not understand that. But most of the American people do, and thatâ€™s why Trumpâ€™s response was not just brilliant and correct, butsavvy, when responding to the call by his opponentâ€™s for top-down centralized control.â€œWhile Joe Biden will allow rioters and looters and criminals and millions of illegal aliens to roam free in our country, he wants the federal government to issue asweeping new mandate to law-abiding citizens, wants the President of the USs with the merestroke of a pen to order over 300 million American citizens to wear a mask for a minimum of threestraight months,â€said Trump on Thursday. â€œI guess he thinks itâ€™s good politics.â€That last rebuke about politics was perfect. I hope whoever wrote it for him getssome kudos.â€œDifferentstates are much different, both in terms of the atmosphere itself and also in terms of the Corona problem. He does not identify what authority the president has to issuesuch a mandate or how federal law enforcement could possibly enforce it or why we would bestepping on governors throughout our country, many of whom have done a very good job and know what is needed it.â€WATCH below, via Grabien. Right on the button. Masks are good, hesaid in thesame presser. Because they are. But mandates, if they exist at all,should be highly local. Thatâ€™s not just commonsense andscientificallysound, itâ€™s the way our nation works.

title: San Diego Unified floats requests to Biden administration in State of District address
content: San Diego Unified Superintendent Cindy Marten released a proposed education plan for president-elect Joe Biden Tuesday during her annual State of the District address. Marten called for increased federal funding forschools and for a national teacher corps program to train more teachers to work in low-incomeschools. Shesuggested the incoming Biden Administration provide $350 billion in COVID-19 aid toschools, fully fundspecial educationâ€”something the federal government has never done â€” triple Title I funding forschools thatserve low-incomestudents, and provide more funding for militarystudents. The new administration alsoshould ensure that all 3- and 4-year-olds have access to quality preschool, Martensaid. She also called for reinstating the National Teacher Corps, a 1965 program that trained teachers to work in disadvantagedschools.â€œNow before anyone discards these ideas as unrealistic given the current economic climate, let me remind you that every one of the San Diegostrategies forschool reform came out of the 2008 financial crisis,â€ Martensaid during a pre-recordedspeech, which was delivered online and received about 2,200 views.â€œHard times breed clarity of purpose. We can create an educational recovery plan that meets the needs of all of ourstudents by focusing on equity.â€Marten warned that the pandemic is causingsevere learning losses because ofschoolshutdowns. A national recovery plan with funding forschools is needed to reverse those losses,shesaid. California publicschools werespared fromstate budget cuts thisschool year, but there is nosuch guarantee for next year.â€œWe now risk losing the progress we have made if we must contend with State budget cuts in January,â€ Martensaid. Marten also described what the district has doneso far during the eight-month long pandemic. Officialssaid the district has distributed more than 80,000 Chromebooks and 8 million free meals to children. Martensaid San Diego is providing more daily, â€œliveâ€ instruction time than other California districts. San Diego Unifiedschools are providing three hours of live instruction each day during distance learning. Marten and School Board President John Lee Evanssaidstudents aresuffering losses due toschool closures, but they didnâ€™tsay how much learning loss is happening among San Diegostudents. The district has not yet released data aboutstudentsâ€™ academic progress during thisschool year. Evanssaid the plan isstill for San Diego Unified to reopen on January 4 for elementarystudents and on January 25 for middle and highschoolstudents. But the reopening could be postponed if San Diego County does not improve its COVID-19 rates quickly enough to get out andstay out of the purple tier.â€œWe all know that ourstudents aresuffering. We know that damage is being done by this pandemic,â€ Evanssaid. â€œEvery person â€” thesuperintendent, the board, and all ourstaff â€” are working diligently to makesure ourschools can open assoon as possible in thesafest possible manner.â€

title: Conservatives Keep Missing Opportunities to Really Engage With Blacks
content: Since the November 3 election, I have received many calls and em ails from influential Republicans and prominent conservatives. Despite losing the White House, they were high-fiving about President Donald Trumpâ€™s going from 8% of the black vote in 2016 to 12% in 2020. What asadstate of affairs when a 12% marketshare is reason to celebrate. In most industries, this would be viewed as unacceptable and embarrassing. Herein lies the problem with the conservative movement: Our expectations areso low when it comes to the black community that even miniscule progress is celebrated jubilantly. The reason expectations areso low is because deep down inside, conservativesâ€“for purposes of this column, Iâ€™m using the words Republicans and conservatives interchangeablyâ€“know that they have not really made aserious effort to cultivate relations with the black community. They do, in their minds, just enough not to be called racist. According to this perverse logic, if they have one black onstaff, they canâ€™t be racist; or if they grew up with a black nanny, they canâ€™t be racist. I am not kidding; I have had many conservations with conservatives along this line. Those who have followed my writing over the years know that I have been critical of the lack of â€œsubstantiveâ€ engagement with the black community from conservatives. Most of the blacks invited by conservatives tospeak at their events have little to no connection to the black community and, quite often, theirspeeches are off-putting to the black community. If your goal is to be entertained or to throw red meat to the white base of the party, then they may be appropriatespeakers. But if your goal is to build relations with the black community, they are counterproductive. I challenge conservatives tospecify the number of blacks they have in decision-making positions within their organizations. How many blacks do they have around them that tell them what they need to hear and not what they want to hear?How many five- andsix-figure black consultants do they have on retainer? How many black vendors do they contract with during the course of a year?When Isay decision-making positions, I meansomeone who can hire or fire; has budgetary authority tospend money; or can get meetingsset up with key executives. This is the 21st century, and many conservative organizations have little to no reflection of the diversity that our country presents. How is this possible?These organizations hire their friends, they give consultant contracts to their friends, they contribute to their friendsâ€™ campaigns. They do thesame things they accuse radical liberals of doing. They are in a bubble, an echo chamber filled with people who only think and look like them. Are they racist? Absolutely not. People tend to gravitate toward the things they are familiar with; itâ€™s a logical and natural thing to do. No, I am not talking about imitating the Democrats. No bean counting. They, as usual, go overboard with their push for diversity, to the point that it is discriminatory. But, if you are a conservative and donâ€™t notice that every time youâ€™re in a meeting or conference that not one black person can be found there, that is a problem. Democrats are obsessed with diversity and Republicans are oblivious to diversity. Both are equally wrong and detrimental to our American values. But true leaders understand this dilemma and make a conscious decision to inject diversity into their organizationsso they can remain relevant. There is no evidence that conservatives have learned this lesson. I have done PR and crises communications forsome of the biggest names in politics, business,sports, and entertainment from all over the world. I refer to myself as a â€œstraticist,â€ not astrategist. Most people in my profession understand PR orstrategic communications, but few understand the merging of both when confronting an issue; thus, the word â€œstraticist.â€The Republican Party and the conservative movement have a brand problem. We have allowed radical liberals to brand us as racist. A lie that is repeated enough becomes the truth. Conservatives are under the misguided notion that blacks need to besold or persuaded on conservatism. Blacks are more conservative than most whites;survey aftersurvey hasshown that blacks are the most churchgoing people in the country. Blacks donâ€™t need to be lectured about family values and entrepreneurship. We had the most intact,stable families from the 1900s to the 1950s, and the highest marriage rates. Then Democrats in the 1960s injected our community with welfare and all these radical liberal â€œsocialâ€ programs. We always have been business-minded, even beforeslavery; until, that is, Democrats cut off our access to opportunities and capital. Conservatism is in our DNA Thesooner conservatives grasp this, thesooner we can begin to makesignificant progress with the black community. Thesooner conservativesstop promoting black minstrelshows dressed up like outreach, thesooner more blacks will publicly join our cause. To cite two examples: The â€œcommentaryâ€ of a certain upwardly mobile young lady and a certain comedic duo, each with their own podcasts, play into the worststereotypes of blacks ever perpetrated. We, as black conservatives, are not here to be used to throw out inflammatory rhetoric against the black community or to entertain a room full of white conservatives with feeble attempts at humor. We want to be a full partner inspreading a positive, conservative message throughout the black community. In the immortal words of my grandmother: â€œBoy, your actionsspeakso loud, I canâ€™t hear a damn thing you aresaying!â€How appropriate for conservatives. Conservatives must first and foremost engage with black entrepreneurs. They are the leaders of the black community, not the preacher-politicians. When all issaid and done,so far there has been moresaid than done.

title: House Democrats make their case to Senate Republicans: Trump duped his rioters â€” and he will dump you
content: "His directive is Trump first," House impeachment manager and Democratic Rep. David Cicilline of Rhode Island reminded the Senate during thesecond day of arguments insupport of thesingular article of impeachment filed against the former president. It is a crucial takeaway thatshould be heeded by the Senate Republicans who plan to acquit Trump, caring not one bit about the overwhelming evidence of his guilt in inciting an insurrection on January 6. Senate Republicans are putting their loyalty to and fear of thesociopathic man-child from Mar-A-Lago over their patriotism and basicsense of decency. But as Cicilline pointed out, no matter what you do for Trump, no matter how much you debase yourself for Trump, no matter what risks you take for Trump, he will not hesitate to throw you under the bus. The impeachment trial of Donald Trump has been overshadowed by the fact that the majority of Senate Republicans plan to acquit Trump. So the only real question is whether or not the House Democrats who are arguing the case against Trump can maximally expose the cowardice and complicity of the Republicans. House Democrats kicked off arguments on Thursday with a compelling presentation by Rep. Diana DeGette of Colorado, focused on how the insurrectionists believed they were there on Trump is orders. "They actually believed they would face no punishment," DeGette explained, noting that the "mobscreamed at officers that they were listening to President Trump" and "believed the commander-in-chief ordered this."The rioters wereso dead certain that they weresafe from consequences, DeGette pointed out, that they did not bother to hide their identities. On the contrary, as most commentators remarked on in the days after the attack, they wereso unafraid that huge numbers of them livestreamed, photographed, or otherwise advertised their participation in the insurrection. The reason these insurrectionists weresure that they'd be free of consequences is not mysterious. It is because Trump promised them that they'd besafe. In thespeech he gavesending the mob tostorm the Capitol, Trump literallysaid, "When you catchsomebody in a fraud, you are allowed to go by very different rules."Even as the House managers argued their case, more evidence emerged proving it. New court documents from the Department of Justice revealed, CNN reported, that the leader of the Ohio Oath Keepers, Jessica Watkins, "believedshe was responding to the call from then-President Donald Trump himself." The documentsshow that Watkins was deeply concerned "about taking action without his backing." As federal prosecutors argued, this was "evident in a November 9, 2020, text in whichshestated, 'I am concerned this is an elaborate trap. Unless the POTUS himself activates us, it is not legit.'"Trump gave the order to "march" on the Capitol and instructed that there is "not going to be cheeringso much forsome of them." The insurrectionists felt like they wereshielded from consequences and free to ransack the building. After all, Trump promised the rules were now "very different."But they were notsafe, as DeGette laid out. Over 200 people have been arrested and chargedso far,some on veryserious charges. Some of the rioters, DeGette noted, havesincesaid they were "duped" by Trump,including Jacob Chansley, the "QAnonshaman" who became the face of the riot with his weird buffalo headdress. On Wednesday,a lawyer for another one of the rioters released astatement complaining that his client, like many who heeded Trump is call, "will bespendingsubstantial portions if not the remainder of their lives in prison as a consequence. Meanwhile Donald Trump resumes his life of luxury and privilege."The evidence does point to the long-standing truth grifters like Trump understand: The best marks are people who think they are part of the conspiracy. That is how Trump gets people. He lures them in by appealing to their ugliest impulses â€” like the growing Republican desire to unfairlyseize power by undermining democracy â€” and then leaves his co-conspirators, who clearly followed Trump because they liked the idea of a fascist insurrection, holding the bag."He lied to his base,saying this was all okay," Rep Ted Lieu of Californiasaid during his argument on Thursday. Democrats finished their case against Trump in a way that was just as impressive as they began it, meticulously laying out the facts while notshying away from the emotions brought on by these terrible events. Lieu was particularly hard-hitting, pointing out that, "When you or I make a mistake andsomething very bad happens, we wouldshow remorse," but Trump is reaction to January 6 was to brag about how perfect his behavior was,showing how intentional this was from the beginning. The Senate Republicans who are lining up toshield Trumpshould really think long and hard about why on Earth they want to protect a man who would not piss on them if they were on fire. A man who always repays loyalty withspit in the face. A man who thanked his vice president, Mike Pence, for years of loyalservice bysending a mob to kill him. A man who, as the House managers amply demonstrated with court documents, did not care who he killed by inciting an insurrection, even if the victims were his mostsycophanticsupporters in Congress. But ultimately, the real question is not whether Trump is guilty. Everyone knows he is. The only question is whether Senate Republicans want to be comp licit with an insurrection that directly threatened their own lives. Presumably, they think they are playing 11th-level chess and will getsome political advantage out of it. But in the end, they are no better than the morons whostormed the Capitol because Trump told them it was "allowed." And if they believe otherwise, it is because Trump hassuccessfully exploited their own overblown egos against them â€” as he does to all of his marks.

title: Mississippi Explicitly Asks the Supreme Court to Overturn Roe vs Wade
content: Thestate of Mississippi made explicit Thursday its attempt to have the Supreme Court overturn,filing a brief that calls on the court to uphold thestateâ€™s current abortion restrictions en route to upending the nearly 50-year-old law that ensures access to abortion procedures in the US Mississippiâ€™s Republican attorney general, Lynn Fitch, filed the brief thatseeks to persuade the court to dust off thesettled law and break with precedent to allow thestateâ€™s prohibition on abortionservices after 15 weeks of a pregnancy tostand. The legalstandard established underRoesaysstates must allow access for abortions performed up until fetal viability around 24 weeks. Mississippi passed the restrictive abortion l awin 2018, along with aslew of anti-abortion provisions that have been blocked by the courts, including a law restricting abortions aftersix weeks. The Supreme Court announced in May that it would hear thecase,setting off alarm among abortion rights activists. Thesuit filed by the Jackson, Mississippi organization, the only abortionservices provider in thestate, contesting the 15-week law wassuccessful in the lower courts, which cited precedent preventingstates from restricting abortion access during the pre-viabilitystage. The Supreme Court, however, after months of hemming and hawing, announced that it would hear thestateâ€™s appeal of the case, raising the possibility it could choose to upend abortion pre-viability abortion restrictions that have been ruled unconstitutional as placing an undue burden on womenseeking an abortion. In announcing its decision, the courtstated explicitly it was out to reassess â€œwhether all pre-viability prohibitions on elective abortions are unconstitutional.â€The announcementsignaled a tectonicshift in US abortion law could be coming now that the court is lopsided with conservative justices. The Mississippi brief attempts to chip away at the viabilitystandard, claiming advances inscience and technology justify thestate intervening earlier and earlier in a pregnancy. Even if the Supreme Court does not explicitly reverse, there are other ways it could defang the law. â€œAs an alternative, Mississippisaid the court could reduce the heightenedscrutiny that abortion laws must meet and find that Mississippiâ€™s law meets legitimate objectivessuch as protecting the unborn, womenâ€™s health or the medical profession,â€ the Washington Postnotes. â€œIt could find that not all pre-viability abortions are unconstitutional, thestatesaid, or that the 15-week restriction does not place an undue burden on asubstantial number of women.â€What is clear is that thestakes are high and, as the Post notes, Thursdayâ€™s â€œbrief emphasizes the potential presented in the case,, the most direct challenge to abortion rights at the Supreme Court in decades.â€ The Supreme Court is likely to hear the case later this year, in November or December, and a decision would be handed down by June of nextyear.

title: Prominent transgender activist in Colombia dies
content: Aprominent transgender activist in Colombia died on Saturday. Laura Weinstein, director of FundaciÃ³n Grupo de AcciÃ³n y Apoyo a Personas Trans (GAAT), a trans rights group based in the Colombian capital of BogotÃ¡, passed away four days aftershe was hospitalized with difficulty breathing.â€œI have been hospitalizedsince yesterday because of breathing difficulties,â€ tweeted Weinstein on December 31. â€œThey gave me a COVID test and we are waiting for the results, but not being able to breath issomething that I never wish upon anyone.â€Gente les gar anti zo que he estado mu y juiciosa y much ossab en que es asÃ­. Desde el dÃ­a de aye r me encuentro hospita liz ada por dificultades respiratorias, me h icier on la prueba#Covidy es per amos el resultado. Pero es to de no po der resp ira r es al go que nunc a le desearÃ­a a nadie.â€” Laura Weinstein N. (@LAURAWEINS)December 31, 2020WilsonCastaÃ±eda Castro, director of Caribe Afirmativo, an LGBTQ advocacy group that works in areas along Colombiaâ€™s Caribbean coast, on Saturday told theWashington Blade that Weinsteinâ€™s coronavirus test came back negative. Weinstein had previously fought cancer. CastaÃ±eda told the Blade her health had deteriorated in recent months.â€œWe mourn the death of GAAT Director Laura Weinstein,â€tweeted Caribe Afirmativo on Saturday.â€œThe joint work and collaborative effort for all these years forged a great friendship between us and her! We are devastated.â€CastaÃ±edatold the Blade that GAAT and Caribe Afirmativo in November requested Colombiaâ€™sNational Electoral Council develop protocols to ensure trans Colombians canvote, regardless of their gender identity. Weinstein over the last year worked with the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria to reduce HIV rates among Venezuelans who have migrated to Colombia. CastaÃ±edasaidshe worked with trans women and in particularsex workers. CastaÃ±eda noted Weinstein a few months ago launched a campaign in BogotÃ¡ tosupport trans women and Venezuelan migrants. Weinstein was also among the Colombian LGBTQ activists who backed the 2016 peace deal between the government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia that ended the countryâ€™s decades-long civil war.â€œWe will always remember her as a great ally, friend and tireless worker for human rights,â€tweetedColombia Diversa, another Colombian LGBTQ advocacy group. TatianaPiÃ±eros,a trans woman who ran for the Colombian Senate in 2018, describedWeinsteinâ€™s death to the Blade as a â€œbig loss.â€MauricioToro,who is the first openly gay man elected to the Colombian House ofRepresentatives, is among those who also mourned Weinsteinâ€™s passing.â€œHer fight and her inspiration will endure forever,â€ he tweeted.
