Trump pointed to a column penned by conservative law professor John Eastman,suggesting that Harris is not eligible toserve as vice president.â€œI heard it today thatshe doesnâ€™t meet the requirements, and by the way the lawyer who wrote the piece is highly qualified, very talented.â€For years, Trump promoted theso-called birth er conspiracy theory aboutBarack Obama,suggesting that his predecessor was not born in the USs. The debunked theory is widely regarded as racist. Trump made the remarks about Harris just two days after the Democratic Partyâ€™s presumptive presidential nominee, Joe Biden, announced her as his running mate. In his op-ed, Eastman argued that the Californiasenator is ineligible toserve as president because her father was a Jamaican national and her mother an Indian national. Neither of the two, he argued, was a naturalized citizen at the time of Harrisâ€™ birth. Eastman pointed to the 12th Amendment and Article II of the US Constitution. He also wrote that Harris cannotserve because of the Citizenship Clause of the 14th Amendment. The law professor concluded that Harrisâ€™ background needs to be reexamined amid reports of Russian and Chinese election interference, writing that â€œit would be an inauspiciousstart for any campaign for the highest offices in the land to ignore the Constitutionâ€™s eligibility requirements.â€Eastman wasslammed for writing the column, with critics pointing out that his views on birthright citizenship are notshared by most constitutional lawscholars. Asnoted, Illinois Sen. Tammy Duckworth was also vetted by Bidenâ€™s team. Although a natural-born citizen, Duckworth was not born in the USs,so Democrats reportedly feared that Trump and his allies would attack her with birth er conspiracy theories.â€œBut with another Black nominee on the ballot, Trump is returning to his wheelhouse, questioning the citizenship of a candidate born in the USs,â€ the publication concluded. In their first joint press conference, Biden and Harris accusedTrumpof leaving the nation â€œin tatters.â€The duo alsoslammed Trumpâ€™s handling of the coronavirus pandemic, with Bidensaying that the commander-in-chiefspends more time golfing than addressing the unprecedented public health crisis. Biden talked about Trumpâ€™s attacks on the California Democrat,suggesting that they do not come as asurprise â€œbecause whining is what Donald Trump does best.â€

title: Professor defends teaching students to question COVID-19 â€˜propagandaâ€™ as NYU investigation continues
content: A New York University professor issuingseveral colleagues for alleged defamation in relation to his unpopular views on COVID-19 interventions, including the efficacy of masks and particular treatments. The private university opened an investigation againstMark Crispin Miller, a tenured professor in the Department of Media, Culture, and Communications, after 25 faculty called on the department to respond to his â€œongoing harm to ourstudents.â€Their letter refers to a September incident in Millerâ€™s class â€œMass Persuasion and Propaganda.â€ A femalestudent, who hassince dropped out of the course, accused him of promoting right-wing conspiracy theories about COVID-19, and the department chair quickly responded that MCC was considering â€œnextsteps.â€Miller () responded bybloggingabout the dispute, asking readers tosign a petition in favor of his academic freedom. He mentioned NYU communications to hisstudents and a department email urging him tostop teaching the course, and claimed he was acting inself-defense. The professor told that NYU Steinhardt School Dean Jack Knott told him the investigation would conclude by the end of thesemester, but gave him no other details. Miller, who hasspent more than 20 years on the NYU faculty, filed a lawsuit in New York State court November 30 after his colleagues did not retract theirstatements and apologize as he demanded. Hesharedseveral NYU communications with to illustrate his legal claims. Miller explained in a phone interview that he wasnâ€™tsuing any of the junior professors whosigned the letter: â€œWhether theysigned it, willingly or not, Iâ€™msure they had no choice.â€According to thesuit, Millerâ€™s colleagues intended to â€œdisgrace and humiliateâ€ the professor â€œunder the guise of phony and uninformed political and cultural correctness and orthodoxy.â€ Heâ€™sseeking $750,000 in damages,saying their letter led to loss of professionalstanding and the worsening of his Lyme disease. The faculty letter â€œtakes every conceivable opportunity to cast me in a bad light,â€ Miller told. He alsosaid in aseparate email that the charges from his colleagues are â€œso false as toseem downright psychotic.â€:Judge tells NYU it canâ€™t punishstudents for breaking after-the-fact COVID rulesIf Miller is a right-wing conspiracy theorist, heâ€™s an unconventional one. The professor isn ame don Turning Point USAâ€™s Professor Watchlist, which identifies faculty who allegedly promote â€œleftist propaganda in the classroom.â€He also helped lead a movement in 2012 to halt NYUâ€™s redevelopment plans for the Greenwich Village campus. The resulting lawsuitsuccessfully challenged nearly half of the universityâ€™s expansion plan, though Miller told the experience also convinced him not tosue NYU itself this time. Politically, Miller considers himself a leftist: â€œIâ€™m anti-war, I believe in empowering the working class, cutting back corporate power â€“ I could go on and on.â€ Hesaid progressive luminariessuch as Robert F Kennedy Jr. and Oliver Stonesigned his petition, and Ralph Nader provided aseparatestatement ofsupport. The Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng, who publicly accused NYUof forcing him out of a fellowship because of pressure from Beijing, alsosigned Millerâ€™s petition, the professorsaid.:NYU declines to testify in Congress about its China campusBut Miller also believes the left has â€œchanged radically over the years. I donâ€™t really recognize it anymore.â€ The left today wants â€œcensorship and government authority to be accepted without questionâ€”except if itâ€™s Trump,â€ hesaid. Some of the professorâ€™s colleagues have long despised him for his course content and extramuralstatements onsubjects including the Sandy Hook massacre and transgender ideology. But a civil liberties group told NYU that Millerâ€™s alleged conduct is expressly protected by its own policies, and cited court rulings against private universities including New York Cityâ€™s Fordham. One group is not weighing in on the dispute: the American Association of University Professors. A representative told in an email that AAUPâ€™s department of academic freedom and tenure confirmed â€œwe havenâ€™t been involved with this case,â€ and declined to comment further. Student Julia Jackson tagged NYU in at weet threadSept. 20 to complain that Miller had â€œspent an entire class period tellingstudents that wearing masks doesnâ€™t prevent thespread of COVID-19.â€ She also claimed that hesaid â€œhydroxychloroquine trials were made to failso more people would be given the vaccine and have their DNA changed.â€She linked to articles and videosshared by Miller, including atwoâ€“partinterview of Canadian physicist Denis Rancourt on One America News Network (), describing them as conspiratorial and â€œfar-right.â€Jacksoncalled onNYU to â€œrelieve himâ€ of educating and advisingstudents. MCC Chair Rodney Benson thanked her for reporting the issue andsaid the department had â€œmade this a priority.â€MillerrespondedOctober 6 on his News From Underground blog, explaining that his pedagogicalstyle is to teachstudents how to identify propaganda drives andseek out alternative claims. He urged hisstudents to readstudies that conclude masks and ventilators are ineffective at preventing transmission of the novel coronavirus andsaving lives, â€œwith due attention to thescientific reviews thereof.â€ Miller cited â€œpossible financial links betweenâ€ researchers and interestssuch as â€œBig Pharma and the Gates Foundation.â€The blog post embedded Jacksonâ€™s tweet thread and mentioned a Sept. 21 email to Millerâ€™sstudents from Knott and Carlo Ciotoli, who leads NYUâ€™s COVID-19 Prevention and Response Team.:Millerâ€™sstudent tries to get him firedMiller provided with this email (below), which hesaid astudent forwarded to him. Prefaced by the claim that NYU has the â€œutmost respect for the principles of academic freedom,â€ it referredstudents to â€œthe most authoritative public health guidanceâ€ â€“ CDCrecommendations.â€œThe evidence backs it up,â€ the email continued, linkingsources. â€œAnd we remind you that wearing a mask is required at NYU.â€ The NYU leaderssaid â€œwe do not feel we have a choiceâ€ in pushing back on Millerâ€™s alleged comments. Millersaid he didnâ€™t tellstudents to break the universityâ€™s mask mandate, which he actively observes â€“ a point emphasized in his lawsuit. The blog post alleged that NYU had urged Miller to cancel his propaganda course because it would be â€œbetter for the departmentâ€ if he instead chose to teach twosections on cinema. (Miller toldSunday that the quoted phrase was from an emailsent by the departmentâ€™s administrative assistant, while a later phone call with Benson, the MCC chair, claimed the change would be better for enrollment.)It linked to ape titi onto back Millerâ€™s cause, which as of Monday night has beensigned by more than 20,000 people. Miller told last week that the blind Chinese lawyer Guangcheng, who memorably escaped house arrest in China, was among them. Guangchengclaimedto have been forced out by NYU following â€œgreat, unrelenting pressureâ€ from Chinese communists, at a time when the university was building a campus in Shanghai. NYUstated that Guangchengâ€™sstay was based on a one-year fellowship and that his claims were â€œboth false and contradicted by the well-established facts,â€ including that the foreign campus was approved to be built before the dissidentâ€™s arrival at NYU The October 21 faculty letter to Steinhardt Dean Knott and Provost Katherine Fleming criticized the views that â€œMiller has espoused on his highly visible websiteâ€ over the years. While it doesnâ€™tsay what is â€œhighly visibleâ€ about Millerâ€™s blog, the letter complains that â€œhe prominently displays his title as a full tenured professor in our department.â€Miller has characterized â€œtransgendersurgery as a eugenic form ofsterilization,â€ mocked transgender people and denied â€œthe Sandy Hook elementaryschoolshooting,â€ they alleged. While Miller has a right to his views, his colleagues object to â€œdiscrimination, attacks againststudents and others in our community, or advocacy for an unsafe learning environment.â€ Students have complained about his discussion of controversial viewpoints and â€œnon-evidence based argumentsâ€ for years, yet frequent complaints to bias review offices and administrators have not â€œimprovedâ€ thesituation. (The letter does not mention anyspecific complaints.)Millerâ€™s post that linked Jacksonâ€™s public tweets opened an opportunity for â€œcyberbullying and threatening communication directed toward thestudent,â€ which â€œsubsequently occurred and continues,â€ the letter claimed. I hope@nyuniversity,@nyusteinhardt, and@mccNYUagree that this professorshould not be trusted with educating and advisingstudents, and I hope they take immediatesteps to relieve him of these duties. 8/â€” Julia Jackson (@julia_jacks)September 21, 2020:Cornell vaccine mandate only applies to whitestudentsIt called for an â€œexpedited reviewâ€ of Millerâ€™s â€œintimidation tactics, abuses of authority, aggressions and microaggressions, and explicit hatespeech,â€ to be followed by â€œwhatever further disciplinary measures are deemed appropriate.â€In an email provided by Miller, Dean Knott told the professor October 29 that an investigation had been opened that day. â€œI will ask Vice Dean for Faculty Affairs LaRue Allen to begin this review immediatelyâ€ and decide, based on the collected information, whether to proceed â€œwith nextsteps as outlined in the Faculty Handbook,â€ Knott wrote. Miller conveyed hisshock at receiving the email in a Thursday phone call with. â€œI was completelysurprised that he hadnâ€™t talked to me first,â€ hesaid. In a Zoom meeting requested by Miller, Knottsaid that NYU â€œlawyers and provost told him that they had toâ€ investigate. Knott wouldnâ€™t give him thescope of the investigation except that â€œthey would talk to people,â€ according to Miller. â€œAnd Isaid what people? And hesaid, faculty andstudents. And Isaid, what faculty? None of them haveseen me teach. And hesaid: well yeah,so thestudents.â€Miller then told the dean that he wouldsolicit andsend testimonials from current and formerstudents, â€œmaybe 40 lettersâ€so far that â€œmake abundantly clear that there is not ashred of truthâ€ in the colleaguesâ€™ letter. He excerptedseveral in his blog post. A few days after this meeting, Miller confronted his colleaguesâ€™ charges in are buttal heshared with. He called â€œnearly allâ€ their claims â€œdemonstrably untrue,â€ and the letter â€œmisleading in its various insinuations.â€ Miller did not launch an email campaign against the department, as they claimed, but rather highlighted â€œNYUâ€™s violation of my academic freedom.â€Miller reiterated his public assertion that hesimply encouragedstudents to read â€œscientificstudiesâ€”eight randomized, controlled trials, conducted among health professionals over the last 15 years orsoâ€”finding that masks are ineffective against transmission of respiratory viruses.â€On Sunday he pointed to his Sept. 5essayâ€œMasking Ourselves to Deathâ€ forsources:researchfrom Rancourt, the Canadian physicist, as well asJoshua Jacobs,BJ Cowling,Faisal bin-Reza,Jeffrey Smith,Vittoria Offeddu,Lewis RadonovichandYoulin Long. The essay mentions the two-part interview with Rancourt and a debate he had with â€œanother COVID-19 dissident,â€ physician Joseph Mercola, whose videos â€œhave been banned on YouTube and Spotifysince mid-June.â€ Miller also provided al ink to Mercolaâ€™s website pertaining to the censorship. Miller emphasized that he â€œvery clearlyâ€ toldstudents that he was â€œtelling you not to wear masks,â€ butsimply engaging in an intellectual exercise. Responding to the email from Knott and Ciotoli, he noted the CDC guidelines â€œthat you regard as gospel truth abruptly changed in early April.â€ Previously they had â€œechoed the consensus of the [randomized controlled trials] that I encouraged mystudents to examine.â€It is â€œwholly falseâ€ that he â€œattackedâ€ Jackson, when in fact â€œthestudent attacked, on Twitter, demanding that NYU fire me.â€ She didnâ€™tspeak up during that class and did not â€œbother reading any of thosestudies,â€ he claimed. â€œHow, and where, and when,Iâ€˜attackedâ€™ her your letter fails tospecifyâ€”as it could not, because I never did.â€NYU professor who questions COVID orthodoxy demands colleagues retract false claims about himbyThe College Fixon Scribd:Stanford lock downskeptic disinvited from academic conferenceBy publicly writing under her own name, Jackson tweets â€œprovoked attacks by others, which had nothing to do with me,â€ Miller continued, adding that he had receivedsimilar attacksspurred by Jacksonâ€™s tweets. (While he mentioned â€œthree media hit-piecesâ€ against him, Miller did not identify the articles.)He only identified Jackson by name once, in the petition defending himself, toshow thatshe demanded his firing. â€œTo cast me as the aggressor in this case is as perverse as your accusing me of having attackedâ€ the department, hesaid. His website does not have â€œasingle mention of Sandy Hookâ€ and he only mentioned theschool massacre in a class discussion on gun control. Miller recommended â€œsome troublingly compellingscholarship on Sandy Hookâ€ tostudents, because â€œwe cannotsimply rule out any argument that deviates from the officialstory.â€ (He exemptedspeculation about child-sex-slave colonies on Mars, whichsaid wasshared by a guest on theAlex Jones Show.)Regarding the alleged transgender mockery, Millersaid the university â€œquickly exculpatedâ€ him fromsecondhand claims by a colleague, defendant Nicole Starosielski, based on â€œthree brief online writings.â€His writing on thesubject is â€œhighly critical of transgenderâ€ because of its â€œtroubling real-world consequencesâ€ insports and prisons and the â€œradical medical intervention in thesexual development of children.â€ The ideology has also been aggressively promoted throughout the corporate media with the backing of â€œmultibillionaires with large investments in Big Pharma,â€ which might have â€œeugenic purposes.â€Miller cited his own â€œpleasantâ€ email exchange with a transgender colleague at NYU Though this personsigned the letter against him, he understands â€œwhyshe may have felt obligedâ€ tosign it. The professorsaid he could make his own allegations about a â€œhostile work environmentâ€ going back â€œsome time, but especially thissemester,â€ citing comments fromstudents about faculty disparaging him. The Foundation for Individual Rights in Education told NYU President Andrew Hamilton in a November 13letterthat the universityâ€™s ownstated commitment to academic freedom meant it must end the investigation into Miller. The civil liberties group noted a New York court ruled in 2019 thatFordham violated its contractual commitments by refusing to recognize a chapter of Students for Justice in Palestine. In a 2018 case closely paralleling the factual allegations in Millerâ€™s dispute, the Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled thatMarquette University could not punish a professorâ€™s extramural expressions because of its contractual promises on academic freedom. NYU did not respond toque ries on how its Miller investigation was any different from the rulings cited by FIRE When the university ignored FIREâ€™s November 20 deadline to respond, the group publicly condemnedNYUâ€™s investigation. Aspokesperson for the civil liberties group told last week that NYU hasstill not responded. Miller has long been a bee in NYUâ€™s bonnet. Heâ€™s one ofseveral named plaintiffs in an ongoing class actionsuit against its â€œmismanagement of our retirement funds,â€ he told. Havingseen the universityâ€™s lawyers in action, Millersaid they are â€œextraordinarily aggressive when it comes to legal action.â€Heâ€™s moresurprised by criticism from colleagues â€“ â€œpeople whom I did everything I could toserve in trying to halt the real estate planâ€ and protecting pension funds. Some of them â€œwrote letters of recommendationâ€ when Miller was â€œnominated for a distinguished teaching award in 2012.â€He emphasized that â€œIâ€™m notsaying this to brag. Iâ€™msaying this to demonstrate how egregious this attack is.â€ Only one faculty member â€“ untenured, from the School of Professional Studies â€“ went to bat for him. Miller is the one person â€œabove allâ€ that the instructor recommends to herstudents,she wrote to President Hamilton and Provost Fleming December 6. (Miller removed the colleagueâ€™s name from the email heshowed.):Trump advisor blasts Stanford colleagues forshutting down COVID-19 debateHis propaganda course is the â€œbestâ€ to makestudents â€œcritical thinkers, a person who can question mass delusions whether they bescientific or political.â€ She compared Miller to Galileo and Copernicus, who were â€œcondemned for exploring unpopular truths.â€The colleague asked rhetorically, whether â€œChristopher Columbus was a hero or whether masks do prevent thespread of a virus, donâ€™t we want to encourage one and all to look at all the material out there?â€Miller told he doesnâ€™t attribute the hostility to his political views, but rather to the â€œdiscomfitureâ€ his work causes colleagues. He closelystudies â€œofficial narratives to determine whether they are true or false and to try to figure out what purpose theyserve and what interests are behind them.â€The political right doesnâ€™t have a monopoly on critiquing the â€œecho chambersâ€ of academia, hesaid: â€œI think itâ€™s also possible to make thesame critique from a left-perspective.â€Millerseessomethingsimilar occurring with the COVID-19 pandemic. â€œJust for urging thestudy on thescientific literature on masking as a barrier against respiratory viruses is like a high crime now; thatâ€™s killing grandma.â€:Profsays anti-maskerssupport whitesupremacy, policy brutalityIMAGE: Renegade Inc./YouTubeLikeon Facebook/Follow us on Twitter

title: Legal scholars 'perplexed' by Pelosi is push against Trump is nuclear codes
content: Legal experts arescratching their heads about House Speaker Nancy Pelosiâ€™s push to prevent President Trump from having the nuclear codes,saying it would curtail the chain of command. In a letter to her Democratic colleagues on Thursday, the California Democratsaidshespoke to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Mark Milley about keeping an â€œunstable president from initiating military hostilities or accessing the launch codes and ordering a nuclearstrike.â€â€œThesituation of this unhinged President could not be more dangerous, and we must do everything that we can to protect the American people from his unbalanced assault on our country and our democracy,â€ Ms. Pelosi wrote. But lawyers noted that unless Mr. Trump was incapacitated under the 25th Amendment or removed from office through impeachment, it would be legally problematic for the commander-in-chief not to be in control of the nuclear codes. Military officers could not bar Mr. Trump from exercising his Article II authority, according to Jonathan Turley, a law professor at George Washington University.â€œI know of no authority by which the nuclear codes can be withheld from the President absent a declaration under Section 4 of the 25th Amendment. Absentsuch a declaration, a denial ofsuch access would be grounds for the removal of any military officer. Thesame is true for the exercise of other executive privileges and powers,â€ Mr. Turleysaid. Similarly, Ilya Shapiro, the publisher of the Cato Instituteâ€™s Supreme Court Review, found Ms. Pelosiâ€™sstatement to present legal trouble unlessshe does pursue impeachment, whichshe has hinted could come next week.â€œItâ€™s definitely a problem. Until and unless the president is removed, either through the 25th Amendment or impeachment, he remains the commander-in-chief. Given Pelosiâ€™sstatement, eithersheâ€™s proceeding with impeachment orsheâ€™ssetting a dangerous precedent for disrupting the civilian chain of command,â€ Mr. Shapirosaid. Democrats have been pushing for Mr. Trump to be impeached asecond time, arguing that he incited hissupporters to break into the Capitol in a violent riot that ended with multiple people dead. They argue the presidentshould never be able toserve in office again, and an impeachment would be a path to ensuring that bar isset. If a president is impeached in the House and convicted by the Senate, the upper chamber then holds asecond vote to bar the individual fromserving in higher office again. It would require 67senators to accomplish their goal. Ms. Pelosi alsosaid in her letter thatshe asked Vice President Mike Pence to invoke the 25th Amendment to remove Mr. Trump, whoshesaid is unstable to continue toserve. She warned if Mr. Pence does not take action, they could move forward in Congress to hold Mr. Trump responsible for the actions of hissupporters following aspeech he delivered from the White House on Wednesday â€” just prior to the violence breaking out on Capitol Hill.â€œIf the President does not leave office imminently and willingly, the Congress will proceed with our action,â€ Ms. Pelosi wrote. Mr. Trump has been telling his voters the 2020 election wasstolen due to alleged fraud. Election officials fromseveralswingstates have dismissed the claims. Ms. Pelosiâ€™s chamber impeached Mr. Trump over a call with the Ukrainian president in late 2018, and the Senate held a trial early last year. The Republican controlled chamber did not vote to remove him at that time. Copyright Â© 2024 The Washington Times, LLC Click here for reprint permission. Click to Read More and View CommentsClick to Hide

title: Army reservist dies of COVID-19 complications in Florida
content: AnArmy Reservesoldier died from complications related to COVID-19 on Monday â€” the fifthservice member to die from the illness caused by the novel coronavirus. Master Sgt. Brian K Tolliver, 46, died in Largo, Florida, after testing positive for COVID-19 on July 10, according to an Army Reserve Medical Command press release.â€œWe feel a tremendous loss in our military family with the passing of Master Sgt. Tolliver,â€said the commandâ€™s ranking officer, Maj. Gen. Jonathan Woodson, in an emailedstatement. â€œCOVID-19 has taken a dedicatedsoldier from our formation, and our thoughts and prayers go out to his family.â€Tolliver, who is from Memphis, Tennessee, was admitted to the Largo Medical Center the day after he tested positive and he remained there until the time of his death, the commandâ€™s releasestated. As of Thursday morning, there have been a total of 34,584 COVID-19 cases amongservice members, with 11,915 of those in the Army,accordingto Pentagon data. More than 19,000service members have recovered from the illnessso far. The Defense Department does not break out those numbers tospecify whether those troops are active duty or reservists. Tolliverserved in the Army for 25 years, more than a decade of which wasspent in the reserve component. In his last assignment, Tolliverserved as the command paralegal for Army Reserve Medical Command in Pinellas Park, Florida. He issurvived by his three children, who reside in Louisville, Kentucky.â€œMaster Sgt. Tolliver was a tremendous mentor, leader,soldier, and one of the finest human beings I have ever met,â€said Lt. Col. T Scott Randall, the deceasedsoldierâ€™s immediatesupervisor. â€œHe will besorely missed by all.â€Four of the militaryâ€™s five deaths have beensoldiers from the Armyâ€™s reserve components. ANew Jersey National Guard captain died of the illness in March at the age of 57. Then in April, a 41-year-oldNavy chief aboard the aircraft carrier Theodore Rooseveltdied. A34-year-old Illinois-based Army Reservesoldier died in May, and a61-year-old Army reservist died earlier this August. The Army Reservesuspended in-person drill in March andshifted to virtual formations and instruction whenever possible, according to a policy memo. The Pentagonâ€™s figuresshow that there have been a total of 75 deaths among DoD personnel, with 47 among civilian employees,seven among dependents, 16 among contractors and the five among uniformedservice members. The infection rate in the military has been roughly on par with that of the general US population, but the rates of hospitalization and death are much lower, likely due to the younger demographics within theservice branches. Fewer than 2 percent of military cases have required hospitalization, and the death rate is 0.0001 percent, compared to 3 percent nationwide, Military Timesreportedin early August. Kyle Rempfer was an editor and reporter who has covered combat operations, criminal cases, foreign military assistance and training accidents. Before entering journalism, Kyleserved in US Air Force Special Tactics and deployed in 2014 to Paktika Province, Afghanistan, and Baghdad, Iraq.

title: Party conventions set ominous tone for November election
content: Joe Biden,standing in an empty convention hall in Delaware, warned that there is no miracle cure for the coronavirus pandemic that has killed more than 180,000 Americans on President Donald Trump is watch. The Democratic presidential nominee, offeringsolace to asuffering nation,said "decency,science, democracy, they are all on the ballot."Trump, hosting a packed GOP convention crowd on the White House South Lawn, told of another apocalyptic future â€” one without law and order, where Democrats would give "violent anarchists and agitators and criminals" free rein over the country. The back-to-back party conventions painted a dark picture of a divided nation andset thestage for a presidential race that portends an epic clash between Republicans promising to restore order and Democrats vowing to restore asemblance of normalcy. In words and images, the unprecedented virtual gatherings also providedsharply contrasting perspectives on asummer of urban unrest as the nation comes to terms with episodes of disturbing police violence against Black men in Minnesota and Wisconsin, both in the heart of the Midwestern battleground. For bothsides, thestakes could not be clearer."They alwayssay that every four years, every election is the most important electionsince the last one, but I think bothsides believe it more deeply than usual,"said David Sturrock, a former Minnesota Republican Party officer and a political-science professor at Southwest Minnesota State University. Ushering forth two well-known nominees in Trump and Biden, the parties kicked off their fall campaigns insomber, existential framing for the November 3 election. For Democrats, that meant appeals tosocial justice and tapping into polling thatshows broad dissatisfaction with the administration is handling of the pandemic. The Republicans' focus on law and order relegated the pandemic to the background, hardly noticeable in thesea of mask less faces coming together for Trump is in-person acceptancespeech on the White House grounds. The event infuriated Democrats andsome conservatives who called it an improper â€” and possibly illegal â€” political use of government property."Get off our lawn," tweeted Minnesota US Sen. Amy Klobuchar, a former contender for the Democratic nomination. Trump reveled in thestately backdrop of the White House, thesort of break from political tradition that delights his followers: "We are here," hesaid, "and they are not."Trump is unapologetic appropriation of the White House, and the National Mall fireworks display that went with it, gave Republicans thesort of patrioticspectacle that animates their America First base. For Democrats, it played into one of their central arguments for his ouster."The message was, in part, are you tired of this [expletive]show? Are you tired of all of this?"said Norman Ornstein, Minnesotan and residentscholar at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, DC "We can go back tosomesemblance of normality with Biden."Republicans centered their message on the riots, looting and destruction across the country, counting on the disorder in Minneapolis and other cities to bringsuburban voters into the Republican fold, whatever their reservations about Trump. Speakers disavowed "cancel culture" and "Woketopians," framingsocialism and anarchy as the greatest threat to the American way of life. Mark and Patty McCloskey, who were charged for allegedly waving their guns as Black Lives Matter protesters marched past their home in StreetLouis, warned that thesame thing could happen to others "watching from quiet neighborhoods" across the country."It is almost like this election isshaping up to be church, work andschool, versus rioting, looting and vandalism,"said Donald Trump Jr., the president isson, on the opening night of the Republican National Convention. While Democrats promised to address racial inequities, voters of color featured in the Republican convention vouched for the Trump administration and policies theysay led to record employment â€” at least before the virus hit."The Republicans know they are not going to pull over asignificant portion of Black voters,so part of that messaging is to moderate whitessaying, 'Look, our party, we are not racist,' "said Michael Minta, a political-science professor at the University of Minnesota who focuses on race and ethnicity. "They aresaying, 'How could this guy be racist if he has these people who are vouching for him and his credibility and integrity?' "Even as the Minneapolis police killing of George Floyd infused a new racialsubtext into election-year politics, Minnesotans were not featured prominently in either convention. Klobucharscored aspeakingslot on the opening night of the Democratic convention. She talked about unity and the right to vote. Republicans tapped Eveleth Mayor Bob Vlaisavljevich, a former Democrat who praised Trump issupport for the mining industry, the lifeblood of the Iron Range, where Republicanssee a bounty of rural white voters. For the broader public, conventions are asignal tostart tuning in to the campaigns. For each party is base, it is a way to rev up its most active members, who typically mingle with their peers in the convention halls and return home andstart on the groundwork of campaigning."There is a certain organizational element to the conventions that helps,"said Vin Weber, a lobbyist and former Republican congressman from Minnesota. "That is missing, you can not do that virtually."Millions of Americans, held captive in their homes by the pandemic restrictions,still tuned in to the twosurprisingly glitch-free virtual conventions. Some pundits note that the ongoing pandemic, the waves of civil unrest and the deepening polarization of politics have done much of the work of motivating voters this year."Emotions are high given everything that is going on, and it is also about how polarized we have become,"said Ben Toff, an assistant professor at the University of Minnesota is journalismschool, who also works at the Center for the Study of Political Psychology. "It is not just an intellectual debate about policy, and frankly, there has not been a lot of policy discussion in these conventions. It is been about identity. Those emotions are very much at thesurface."Briana Bierschbach â€¢ 651-925-5042Twitter: @bbierschbach

title: Tuberville flipped most of the urban counties in Alabama back to the GOP
content: Heading into Tuesdayâ€™s election, US Sen. Doug Joneswas already facing an uphill climb. In order to have a chance at reelection, Alabamaâ€™s Democratic incumbent didnâ€™t just need to win in thestateâ€™s most populous counties. He needed to run up thescore. Instead, GOP challenger Tommy Tuberville did well in the cities andsuburbs, winning eight of the 10 largest counties in thestate on his way to a 20 point win. He flipped four of those large counties back to GOP Jones wonsix of the 10 largest counties in 2017, including two of the top three. In 2017, Jones carried Madison County, home of Huntsville in north Alabama, and Mobile County on the coast. In thatspecial election, Jones won around 57 percent of the vote in each of those counties. On Tuesday he lost both. Out of the 10 largest counties in Alabama, only Jefferson and Montgomerystuck with Jones.[Canâ€™tsee the map?Click here.]And while Jones did win in Jefferson County - the most populous in thestate and and his home county - hesignificantly under performed there compared to 2017. This year he edged Tuberville in Jefferson with 54 percent of the vote. In 2017, Jones earned a whopping 68 percent of the vote in Jefferson, in a year where turnout was very low. Jones also won Montgomery on Tuesday, part of the traditionally Democratic Black Belt and the fourth largest county in Alabama. He performed well throughout the Black Belt, which other than Montgomery issparsely populated. Jones pulled 67 percent of the vote in Montgomery, but that wasstill asmaller victory than he earned in 2017, when he won Montgomery with 72 percent. Tuberville also flipped Lee County, home to Auburn, and Tuscaloosa County, both of which Jones carried in 2017. In fact, Tuesdayâ€™s resultshows just how much of an anomaly the 2017special election was. Even if Jones had replicated his percentages in thestateâ€™s largest counties, Tubervillestill would have won handily. Do you have an idea for a datastory about Alabama? Email Ramsey Archibald atrarchibald@al.com, and follow him on Twitter@RamseyArchibald. Read more Alabama datastorieshere.

title: Where the heck is Joe Biden as anti-Semitic attacks engulf America?
content: Low-grade pogroms against Jews aresweeping the US Hamas thugs are unleashing violent unprovoked violent assaults on Jews innocently going about their business in US cities - inNew York, Los Angeles, Arizona, New Mexico, andFlorida, with leftistssaying 'do not blame me.' Some leftists are repeating their old trope that they are merely anti-Zionist, not full-blown Jew-haters no different from the Klan or other low-class dirtbags. For appearances isake, most are payingsome kind of lipservice to condemning this apparently organized Hamas thuggery appearingsuddenly on ourshores, even as they continue to claim with forked tongues that Israel is the problem. Joe Biden, though, is the exception. He has notsaid a damn thing. Hestill remains AWOL as Jews are hunted down and assaulted in hate crimes, raising questions, at least in my mind, as to whether Hamas hassomething on him. He issaid nothing. His Twitter feed is a wasteland and his White Housesite issilent. 'Silent Joe' is his way with this one, and it is not a compliment. Biden can reliably be counted upon to condemn other hate crimes and perceived transgressions -- he condemned anti-Asian hate crimes, for one, and of course, calls any incident involving a blacksuspect and a white cop  isystemic racism,' which makes hissilence in the case of thisshocking wave of attacks all the more remarkable. It is certainly been noticed in any case. According to Ben Samuels, writing inHa'aretz:The Anti-Defamation League, American Jewish Committee, Hadassah: The Women is Zionist Organization of America, Jewish Federations of North America, and the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America wrote Biden on Friday highlighting aspike in reported violent incidents targeting Jews in the US and abroad, as well as onsocial media. TheADLsaid Thursdayit wasseeing "a dangerous and drasticsurge in anti-Jewish hate" after the outbreak of renewed hostilities between Hamas and Israel, "from London to Los Angeles, from France to Florida, in big cities like New York and insmall towns, and across everysocial media platform."The organizations call onBidento call out antisemitism, telling him to "harness the authority of the Presidency and the USs Government tospeak out loudly and clearly against antisemitism."According to AJ Kaufman, writing atThe Lid:While many wonder whetherIran-backed Hamaswill oblige [on a cease fire with Israel after itstarted its rocket attacks], we also wonder why President Joe Biden has not been more outspoken, not only insupporting our chief ally in the Middle East, Israel but in condemning violence against Jews in America. Each year,FBIstatsshowJews are overwhelmingly the victims of more anti-religious â€œhate crimesâ€ than any eth no religious group. And these numbers continue in May,ironically Jewish American Heritage Month. Joe may be AWOL on the border, but he is even more AWOL on this. As with the border meltdown, hissilencesuggests consent. Biden issilence is most likely due to his innate cowardice and his consummate political considerations. According to New York Post columnist Michael Goodwin, as president, heshifts like a weather vane to the political winds. He hides, he appears, he calls a lid, but the bottom line is, he is concerned only about one thing politically: Keeping the far left wing of his party ever loyal to him as his political footsoldiers. That is where the biggest Jew-haters roost. Start with the far-left Squadside of things. Writing in theNew York Post, Goodwin believes there was a weird turning point in Joe is behavior around this priority of his:A defining moment came last Tuesday when Michigan Rep. Rashida Tlaib, the first Palestinian woman elected to Congress, confronted Biden at the Detroit airport and argued American aid to Israel was funding atrocities against Palestinians. The tarmac face-off lasted eight minutes, and Biden later lavished praise on Tlaibâ€™s â€œpassion and concern forso many people.â€ Presumably, her concern doesnâ€™t include the Jews Hamas vows to eliminate. The irony here is that while even full-blown Jew-haterssuch as Tlaib and Reps. Ilhan Omar and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez pay lipservice to condemning anti-Semitic attacks, as I wrote abouthereyesterday, Joe will not condemn even those. There is more than the Squad, though, in the mind of Joe -- there is also the Democratic Party is black congressional leaders and activists, who have embraced the likes of Louis Farrakhan and the Rev. Al Sharpton, two notorious anti-Semites, as if they represent all black voters, and are ineffably tied to the mast of the Democrat party. After aspate of anti-Semitic attacks by black extremists in 2019, I noted thishere. Why is that? [Why are these attacks happening?] Because Democrats have been coddling black anti-Semites for years. Where is the Democratic condemnation for race huckster Rev. Al Sharpton, who is also a notorious anti-Semite with a long record of incitement of violence against Jews? Right there in the berth of the Democratic Party,stillsupposedly representing the black "middle class."Where is the Democrats' condemnation for Louis Farrakhan, whose animating breath is all about anti-Semitism? Hobnobbing with Democrats in photos, appearing with Bill Clinton at Aretha Franklin is funeral, and tweeting "sweetheart" dreck with fellow anti-Semite, Democratic Rep. Ilhan Omar. Where, for that matter, is the Democratic condemnation of Rep. Ilhan Omar is anti-Semitism? They could not pass asimple resolution against her in the House after herstring of whoppers. They were too afraid to lay a hand on her, despite her long record of anti-Semiticstatements. It is coddling all right, and you can bet the more aggressivestreet predator class of black cultists,such as "Black Hebrew Israelites" a known anti-Semitic black group, and Jew-haters in the boroughs noticed the pattern, took note, and launched their reign of terror. Still no recognition of the problem from Democrats, though. They prefer to call it the bad deeds of individuals and then let them off lightly. That is a recipe of worse to come. In Joe is mind, though, it is best to keep these moral zeros happyso they will deliver the black vote for Joe. This, despite, or maybe because of, President Trump is heavy inroads on winning over the black vote to Republicans in 2020. Elections are going to be tough for Democrats going forward,so Joe is going all in on following the Sharpton way and keeping Calypso Louie content, both creeps laughing up theirsleeves at him, in the interest of using their political muscle to perpetuate his own political power. This is more than justspeculation. Sharpton, for one, visited the Obama White House with Joe Biden thesitting vice president72 times, according to leftist PolitiFact, and according to Wisconsin GOP Congressman Glenn Grothman, and former Mayor of New York Rudy Giuliani, it was probably a higher figure. Whatever the number of times, it was a big number with a bottom at 72, obviously underlining to Old Joe that political power for Democrats depends on the love of Jew-hating Al Sharpton. Obama taught Biden everything he knows and probably continues toserve as ashadow president. This is a vile dynamic, no two ways about it. Biden is keepingsilent for a reason and the multiplying nests of anti-Semitism within his own party amount to a vehicle for him. He thereforestayssilent as raw anti-Semitism rears its ugly head and pogrom-like violencespirals across the US, expecting reliably Democrat-voting Jews to let it go, and expecting the whole thing to go away. It will not. Image:Gage Skidmore, via Flickr//CC BY-SA 2.0To comment, you can find the MeWe post for this articlehere.
