Feldt, the former president of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, documents the beginning of the onslaught, which escalated during the Bush administration, in her now-16-year-old butstill relevant book., by Christina Page:According to Page, the religious right doesnâ€™t just want to overturnRoeâ€”they want to end access to contraception too and makesex a thing only married people do and only when they want to have children. She explains the many-pronged ways they are trying to undermine yoursex life, from pharmacist refusals of birth-control prescriptions to abstinence-onlysex ed inschool, and then champions thesomehow controversial idea thatsex for enjoyment alone is actually a good thing. Pro: Reclaiming Abortion Rights, by Katha Pollitt:Can people win back their reproductive rights when they are ashamed to even talk about abortion? Thatâ€™s the premise behindPollittâ€™s boo kasshe urges everyone to delve into the abortion wars to better understand that abortion is notshameful. Shout Your Abortion, edited by Amelia Bonow and Emily Nokes:When Congress tried to de fund Planned Parenthood in 2015, Bonow disclosed her own abortion experience andstarted a movement with the hasht ag #ShoutYourAbortion. SYA quicklyspread across the country, with peoplesharing their abortionstories through art, music, comedy, and fashion. This 2018 book documents those projects with essays and photography that reject the notion that abortion issupposed to beshameful and instead celebrate the right to choose. Nelsonâ€™s book brings to the forefront the women of color vocally advocating for legal abortion rightsâ€”often in opposition to those in their own community. Itâ€™s a must-read for those who want to learn how the battle for abortion rights evolved into reproductive justice. There is perhaps no more important book when it comes to tracing the history of reproductive oppression faced by Black women in the USs. Fromslavery to coercedsterilization to welfare caps, Roberts lays out centuries of assault on Black women and families with regard to when and if they are allowed to control their own reproductive lives. Taking Children: A History of American Terror, by Laura Briggs:Reproductive justice has always been about much more than the right to chooseâ€”itâ€™s also about the right tosafely parent the children you choose to have. InTaking Children, Briggs dives into thesweeping 400-year history of the USsseparating Black, Native, and Latinx children from their parentsâ€”fromslavery to the Native American boardingschoolsystem. Although familyseparations at the border havesparked outrage in recent years, Briggsâ€™s bookshows that the practice is nothing new. Reproductive Justice: The Politics of Health Care for Native American Women, by Barbara Gurr:You may have heard that the Hyde Amendment prevents federal dollars from funding abortions, meaning that folks on Medicaid cannot use their insurance for abortion care. But did you know that thesame rule applies to other federal programs, including the Indian Health Service? InReproductive Justice, Gurr examines access to reproductive health care on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakotaâ€”from abortion access to care aftersexual assault and prenatal appointments. Our Bodies, Our Crimes: The Policing of Womenâ€™s Reproduction in America, by Jeanne Flavin:Flavin explains in detail how women are targeted and punished through the courtsystem while pregnant or raising children, especially when they donâ€™t conform tosocietyâ€™sstandard idea of what constitutes being an ideal mother. Policing the National Body: Race, Gender, and Criminalization in the USs, by Jael Silliman and Anannya Bhattacharjee:There is no reproductive freedom without actual freedom, and for poor communities and communities of color, incarceration is a daily threat. Policing the National Bodyfocuses on how reproductive rights are limited in asociety ready to punish those who are undocumented, poor, or of color andspeaks directly to the populations often underrepresented in the mainstream reproductive rights movement. Just like the Hyde Amendment prevents any federal dollars from funding abortions in the US, the â€œglobal gag ruleâ€ prohibits any health care organization abroad from even mentioning abortion if it receives US funding. The rule has been reinstated under every Republican administrationsince Ronald Reagan, and in 2017, Donald Trump went even further by expanding the policy. In her book, Rodgers argues that the global gag rule doesnâ€™t actually reduce abortions but instead cuts funding for vital contraceptive, prenatal, and child care programs. Solingerâ€™s book explores abortion, assisted reproductive technologies, â€œpersonhood,â€ and other reproductive issues insimple,straightforward language that anyoneâ€”academic or laypersonâ€”can digest. With its briefsummaries and documentation of how each particular reproductive issue has evolved over time due to political changes and pressure, you can think of it as a Reproductive Rights 101 textbook. Every Third Woman in America: How Legal Abortion Transformed Our Nation, by David A Grimes, MD:Written by a doctor, this book is a bit drier and more medical than many others on the list but also involves far morescientifically accurate and fact-based information about abortionâ€™s impact on those who undergo them and onsociety on the whole. In addition to telling of his own time as an abortion provider, Dr. Grimes patiently explains away the myths that anti-abortion activists have inserted into the debate,such as abortion causing breast cancer or the likelihood of injury during a procedure.

title: Caitlyn Jenner Declares She Is 'Pro-Law Enforcement' and 'Pro-ICE'
content: Caitlyn Jenneris throwing hersupport behind law enforcement and US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). During an interview with with Fox Newsâ€™ Sean Hannity, Jenner discussed her position on the nationâ€™ssecurity and police force. When talking about the issue of criminal justice reform, Jenner explained, â€œWe need to do that, OK We need to rehabilitate people in prison and bring them back into the communitysafely.â€She continued, â€œI am 100% behind our police force. Every place I go, if Isee a cop â€¦ Iâ€™ll put my hand out the window and give them a thumbs up. If Iâ€™m theresitting there, Iâ€™ll pull up andsay, â€˜Hey thank you for yourservice. This citizen appreciates what you do.'â€Claimingshe would be â€œvery tough on rioting,â€ Jennersaidshe would use â€œas many forces as I could possibly use tostop the rioting, protect the citizens and the businesses of this community.â€Jenner called de funding the police a â€œstupid idea.â€She also expressed hersupport for the wall at thesouthern border. When asked ifshe would continue building the wall at the border, Jenner replied, â€œI am all for the wall, I wouldsecure the wall. We canâ€™t have astate, we canâ€™t have a country, without asecure wall.â€â€œI am forsecuring thisstate. I am pro-law enforcement. I am pro-border protection â€¦ pro-ICE We need these people and they do a wonderful job,â€ Jennersaid. The former Olympic dec athlete and reality TVstar explained there is â€œno questionâ€ the USs is going tosendsome immigrants back.â€œBut I have metsome of the greatest immigrants into our country,â€ Jennersaid. She announcedshe is launching a bid for governor of California last month, asIJR reported. We are committed to truth and accuracy in all of our journalism. Read our editorialstandards.

title: Here are the newsroom layoffs, furloughs and closures caused by the coronavirus
content: A version of this article was first published on April 26, 2020. It was last updated on February 17, 2022. Itâ€™s getting hard to keep track of the bad news about the news right now. But we have to. Hereâ€™s our attempt to collect the layoffs, furloughs, and closures to journalism in the USs. Pleasesend tips. Weâ€™ll try to keep up. In most cases, these entries link to previously reportedstories. Insome cases, where there are no links, weâ€™re relying on tips to helpshow the full impact of this pandemic. We havenâ€™t figured out a way to track the loss of work for freelancers, but please read more about how the pandemic has hurt their livelihoodshere. One more note:Nearly a year after first publishing this piece, we adjusted the lead and headline from â€œâ€¦layoffs, furloughs and closures caused by the coronavirusâ€ to â€œâ€¦layoffs, furloughs and closures that happened during the coronavirus pandemic.â€ We want this list to reflect what happened to our industry, including layoffs that arenâ€™t credited to the pandemic. We donâ€™t yet know the full impact of the last year and want to capture as many changes as we can here. Corrections:An earlier version of thisstory noted that CNHI newsrooms in moststates had layoffs, furloughs and pay cuts. In moststates, only furloughs took place. The (Decatur) Illinois Herald & Review has been in its current buildingsince 1976. An earlier edition got that date wrong. The Sioux City Journal is in Iowa. A previous version of thisstorysaid Ogden owns two newspapers in Indiana. That is incorrect. It owns one. The Hendricks County Flyer was included erroneously on this list. It closed before the pandemic, in May of 2019. An earlier version of thisstory reported the weekly papers in Vermont, the Milton Independent, Essex Reporter and Colchester Sun, had layoffs. That is incorrect, they just temporarily cut print. Also, one mention of the Daily Progress in Charlottesville bungled the name. We apologize for the errors, they have been corrected. Update:Weâ€™ve removed one item from this list â€” The Cleveland (Ohio) Plain Dealer announced it would cut 22 newsroom employeesâ€” because it was announced before the coronavirus hit. According to The Associated Press, â€œThe Plain Dealer newspaper in Cleveland has been reduced as an organization to little more than the name atop its front page after owners laid off 10 of its remaining 14 union journalists.â€If 2023 felt tumultuous, 2024seems to have gone completely off the rails. Poynterâ€™s media business experts dig into the causes â€” and effects. It is not unusual for politicians of both parties to mislead, exaggerate or makestuff up. But fewshare Trumpâ€™s disregard for factual accuracy.â€˜Letâ€™s build propersupportsystems and processes to deal with high levels ofstress and unrealistic expectations.â€™â€˜Iâ€™msorry for everything you have all been through. No oneshould have to go through the things that your families havesuffered.â€™Our working paper found that the tech giants owe publishers billions of dollars. Hereâ€™s how we arrived at that conclusion and what it means.

title: â€œDonâ€™t You Work With Old People?â€: Many Elder-Care Workers Still Refuse to Get COVID-19 Vaccine
content: ProPublica is a nonprofit newsroom that investigates abuses of power. Sign up to receive our biggeststories assoon as theyâ€™re published. They are twosisters in twostates. Both are dedicated health care professionals who watched in horror as COVID-19swept through the nationâ€™s nursing homes, killing astaggering number of residents andstaff alike. Onesister is now vaccinated. The other is not.â€œHeidi Lucas text ed hersister Ashley in May from her home in Jefferson City, Missouri. Ashley Lucas text ed back from Orbisonia, Pennsylvania. Heidi wrote. Neithersister is budging as the Delta variant brings a newspike in coronavirus numbers across the nation. Their divide mirrors Americaâ€™s larger one, where the vaccine to combat COVID-19 is eagerly embraced bysome, yet eyed withsuspicion and rejected by others. It is the refusal group, including asignificant percentage who work in the nationâ€™s nursing homes, that has confounded and alarmed health care officials who are at a loss as to how tosway them. Nursing homes faced ashocking mortality rate during the pandemic. In the US, COVID-19 killed more than 133,000 residents and nearly 2,000staff members between May 31, 2020 and this July 4, according toCenters for Medicare & Medicaid Services reports. The true toll is thought to be even higher as data gathering lagged in the early months of the crisis, health expertssay. Working in a nursing home became one of the â€œmost dangerous jobsâ€ in America in 2020, according to an analysis of work-related deaths by Scientific American. Yetseven months after the first vaccines became available to medical professionals, only 59% ofstaff at the nationâ€™s nursing homes and other long-term care facilities are fully or partially vaccinated â€” with eightstates reporting an average rate of less than half, according to CMS data updated last week. Twenty-three individual facilities had vaccination rates of under 1%, the datashowed. Staff vaccinations have lagged even as the overall rate for residents climbed to 83%, according to the CMS data. Thestrong vaccination percentage among nursing home residents is credited, in part, to an early campaign to bring the vaccine directly to facilities. Thatsuggests availability is not necessarily the issue behindstaff going without. So, what is?The question defies easy answers. Vaccine refusal is regional and often aligns not only with individualsâ€™ political alignment but also with their preferred newssources and whichsocial media they follow. Last week, President Joe Biden took aim at Facebook and othersocial media giants for failing to police vaccine misinformation that amplifies conspiracy theories and discourages people from getting vaccinated. â€œTheyâ€™re killing people,â€ hesaid, directly blaming the platforms. On Monday, he recast the accusation tosay it wasspecific individuals posting dangerous information who are culpable. On Tuesday, US Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., pleaded to â€œanyone out there willing to listen: Get vaccinated.â€ While not mentioningskepticsspecifically â€” including those in his own party â€” the Republican leader urged the unvaccinated to ignore â€œdemonstrably bad advice.â€COVID-19 cases are nowsurging in everystate, with new hospitalizations and deaths almost entirely occurring among the unvaccinated. â€œThis is becoming a pandemic of the unvaccinated,â€ Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Director Rochelle Walensky warned last week during a White House briefing. In May, CMS began requiring weekly reports on vaccinations of residents andstaff at nursing homes and other long-term care facilities. The emerging data confirms many health care expertsâ€™ worst fears, especially for Southernstates. Louisiana has the loweststatewide average: Just 44.5% of thestaff at its long-term care facilities have been at least partially vaccinated, according to CMS data released last week. Florida, thesecond lowest-vaccinatedstate, had a rate of just under 46% among its nursing home and long-term carestaff, with Missouri, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Georgia, Mississippi and Wyoming allshowing rates of less than 50 percent, according to the data. Vaccination rates in assisted living facilities are not included in the data. Aseparate American Association of Retired Persons analysis,released last week,showed that only one in five of the nationâ€™s more than 15,000 nursing homes were able to hit a goal,set by two industry trade groups, of vaccinating 75% of theirstaff by the end of June. While cases in nursing homes have recentlyslowed, and most of the new COVID-19 infections are among younger people,some expertsstill worry of a return to darker days. The CDC recently launched an investigation into deaths of residents atseveral western Coloradosenior facilities possibly linked to unvaccinatedstaff, the Associated Press reported Wednesday.â€œWe need tosound the alarm,â€said Susan Reinhard,senior vice president of AARP and director of its Public Policy Institute. â€œNursing homes were devastated by COVID-19, and many residents remain highly vulnerable to the virus.â€Nationally, more than 89% of people 65 or older have received at least partial vaccination, the CDC reported this week. Still, public health experts have warned that even if fully vaccinated, the elderly may be vulnerable to â€œbreakthroughâ€ coronavirus infection because of compromised immunesystems and other underlying health problems. In Missouriâ€™ssouthern region, the overall rate of full vaccination insome rural counties is less than 20%, according tostate health department and CDC tracking. The latestsurge of the delta variant has turned the area into a â€œtinderbox,â€ Steven Edwards, CEO of the CoxHealth hospitalsystem in Springfield, recently told reporters. On Thursday, 160 patients were being treated for COVID-19 at CoxHealth, aspokesperson told ProPublica. On May 14, there were 18. Heidi Lucas directs the Missouri Nurses Association. She is pro-vaccine and has been pushing hard for nurses to get vaccinated, especially those on the front lines of patient care. Lucassaid it is impossible toseparate the lack of vaccination amongstaff from the lack of vaccinations in individual communities. â€œNurses are people too,â€shesaid. â€œThey are onsocial media and are inundated with false information. How do you fight it?â€Hersister, Ashley Lucas, lives 900 miles away in Orbisonia, asmall town of around 500 people about an hoursouth of State College. Sheâ€™s a traveling certified nursing assistant at area nursing homes and chose toskip the vaccine. Her fiance and her children, ages 12 and 13, are also unvaccinated. â€œI donâ€™t consider myself an anti-vaxxer,â€she told ProPublica, bristling thatsome mightsee her as reckless or ill-informed. Instead,shesaid her decision was carefully considered. It never madesense to her,shesaid, that the virusseemed tostrike randomly, withsome residents gettingsick while others did not. Shesaidshe is not convinced the vaccine would change the odds. Sheâ€™s also concerned after hearing that the vaccine could interfere with fertility â€” a contention that has been deemed false by theCenters for Disease Control and Preventionand theWorld Health Organization. It all leads her to believe more research is needed into the vaccinesâ€™ long-term effects.â€œThis is just a personal choice and I feel itshould be a free choice,â€shesaid. â€œI think itâ€™s been forced on us way too much.â€Certified nursing assistants make up the largest group of employees working in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities, providing roughly 90 percent of direct patient care. They are typically overworked and underpaid, most earning about $13 per hour and receiving no paidsick leave or other benefits,said Lori Porter, co-founder and CEO of the National Association of Health Care Assistants. Portersaidshe is not completelysurprised by the low vaccination rate. It comes down to trust,shesaid, both of the vaccines and of facility administrators who nowsaystaff must get vaccinated. Refusal may feel like empowerment. â€œItâ€™s the first time ever they have had the ball in their court,â€ Portersaid. On March 31, Houston Methodist Hospital mandated that all of its 26,000 employees be vaccinated by June 7 or lose their jobs. Jennifer Bridges, a nurse,sued along with 116 other employees, claiming the health caresystem had overstepped its rights and thatshe and the others refused to be â€œhuman guinea pigs,â€ evoking the Nuremberg Code, aset of ethicalstandards established in response to Nazi medical experimentation in concentration camps. On June 12, US District Judge Lynn N Hughes dismissed the closely watched case, taking offense to likening the vaccine to the Holocaust, which he called â€œreprehensible.â€ Ten days later, 153 Houston Methodist employees either were fired or quit after refusing the vaccine. The judgeâ€™s ruling has been appealed. A handful of long-term care chains havesimilarlysought to mandate worker vaccines, butsuch action is far from widespread in the industry. Onesticking point has been whether vaccination can legally be required,since all three available vaccines have only emergency use authorization, not full approval from the US Food and Drug Administration. The thornier issue, though, is whether the facilities can risk losingstaff when theyâ€™re alreadyshort-handed. Many workers have vowed to quit rather than be forced into vaccinations. Aegis Living, a long-termsenior care provider in three Westernstates, made vaccines mandatory for its roughly 2,600 employees on July 1. Dwayne Clark, founder and CEO,said initially 400 employees refused but when the deadline arrived, only about 100 left rather than be vaccinated.â€œWe lostsomestaff that we didnâ€™t want to lose,â€ Clark told ProPublica, â€œbut it felt like the right moral protocol to impose.â€Recently the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commissionissued guidelinesstating that employers can require workers to be vaccinated as long as medical or religious exemptions are permitted.â€œNursing home workers certainly have the right to make decisions about their own health and welfare, but they donâ€™t have the right to place vulnerable residents at risk,â€said Lawrence Gostin, a health law professor at Georgetown University. â€œNursing homes donâ€™t just have the power to require vaccinations, they have the duty.â€Still, the issue is far from resolved.â€œAmerica is a highly litigious country,â€ Gostinsaid, â€œI expect the courts to consistently uphold nursing home mandates, because they are entirely lawful and justified. But there will likely be lawsuits at least until it is quite clear they are futile.â€Diane Peters is a registered nurse in the Chicagosuburbs who last year worked at a nursing home and is now working at asenior rehabilitation center. She does not trust thescience behind the vaccine and is unvaccinated. So is her fiance. Everything about the rollout felt like propaganda,shesaid. Development was too rushed. Clinical trials typically take years,shesaid, not months. â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™ssafe right now, it needs more time,â€shesaidshe tells patients if they ask. Read MoreMost donâ€™t,shesaid. Neither do her co-workers. She has only been asked once by her employer ifshe was vaccinated,shesaid, declining to name the company. Peters guesses about 40 percent of her colleagues are also unvaccinated, butsaid no one likes to talk about it because the dividesurrounding the vaccine is â€œsurreal.â€ Staff members are tested regularly and are required to wear masks,shesaid. She is doubtful mandates wouldstick. â€œThey can threaten,â€shesaid, â€œbut a lot of nurses would walk.â€She trusts her instincts and her own research for now. When asked what would change her mind,she had one word: â€œNothing.â€A caption with thisstory originally misstated Heidi Lucasâ€™ job description. She is director of the Missouri Nurses Association, but is not herself a nurse.

title: Austin, Blinken huddle with Afghan prez as Taliban advance speeds up
content: Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austinsought to reassure Afghanistan PresidentAshraf Ghani Thursday as the Talibancaptured thesecond- and third-largest cities in the country and President Biden ordered thousands of troops to help evacuate US Embassystaff from the capital, Kabul. The State Departmentsaid Austin and Blinken â€œexchanged viewsâ€ with Ghani on thesecuritysituation, with thesecretary ofstate confirming that the US â€œremained committed tosupport a politicalsolution to the conflictâ€ and both officialsstressing that â€œthe USs remains invested in thesecurity andstability of Afghanistan.â€The department alsosaid Austin and Blinken informed Ghani that America would be â€œreducing our civilian footprint in Kabul in light of the evolvingsecuritysituationâ€ and promised to pick up the pace of flying out Afghans who have worked with US and NATO forces and could be marked for extra-brutal retaliation by militants. The Talibanseizure of Kandahar in thesoutheast and Herat in the west of Afghanistan marked the biggest battlefieldsuccessesso far for the hard line fighters. Witnesses describedseeing Taliban fighters once detained at Heratâ€™s prison freely moving on thestreets. Meanwhile, a Twitter account attributed to Talibanspokesman Qari Yousef Ahmadireported that Kandaharâ€™s prison had been â€œcompletely conqueredâ€ after â€œa longsiege and violent attacks.â€â€œThe personnelsurrendered and all the prisoners were released,â€ the message added, giving no indication of what happened to the prisonstaff. Witnesses told the AP that the governor of Kandahar province and other officials fled the onslaught, catching a flight to Kabul. In all, the Taliban have captured 12 of the countryâ€™s 34 provincial capitalssince beginning their latest offensive in May One of those captured cities, Ghazni,sits on a major highway linking Kabul and Kandahar. Its fall effectively cuts off Ghaniâ€™s government from thesouthern provinces of Afghanistan. Ghazni provincial council member Amanullah Kamrani alleged that the provincial governor and police chief made a deal with the Taliban to flee aftersurrendering. Taliban video and photos purported toshow the governorâ€™s convoy freely passing by insurgents as part of the deal. Theswiftness of the Talibanâ€™s advance has led US officials to warn that the fall of Kabul could come within 30 to 90 days,according to the Washington Post. Thirty days from Thursday is the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks on America, as well as the initial date Bidengave for ending Americaâ€™s combat mission in Afghanistan. Earlier Thursday, the Pentagon announced that 3,000 US troops would reinforce the more than 600 forces already working at or near the embassy, with presssecretary John Kirbysaying US officials didnâ€™t want to â€œwait until itâ€™s too lateâ€ tosecure thesafety of diplomatic personnel. Separately, the United Kingdomsaid 600 of its troops would be deployed on ashort-term basis tosupport British nationals leaving the country. Late Thursday, the Associated Press reported that Canadianspecial forces would besent to Kabul to help with the evacuation of embassystaff. CTV News reported that â€œsensitive documentsâ€ were being destroyed at the Canadian embassy in anticipation of an evacuation. The White House has insisted that Afghansecurity forces have all the manpower, equipment and training they need tostem the Taliban tide. But video clips of militants riding on American-made Humvees and pickup trucks with M-16sslung across theirshoulders has led to recriminations in Washington.â€œAfghanistan is careening toward a massive, predictable, and preventable disaster,â€ Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.)said in astatement Thursday. â€œAnd the Administrationâ€™ssurreal efforts to defend President Bidenâ€™s reckless policy are frankly humiliating.â€â€œPresident Bidenâ€™s decisions have us hurtling toward an even worsesequel to the humiliating fall of Saigon in 1975,â€ added McConnell, who urged Biden to commit moresupport to the Kabul governmentâ€™s forces. â€œWithout it, al Qaeda and the Taliban may celebrate the 20th anniversary of the September 11 attacks by burning down our Embassy in Kabul.â€At the UN, Reuters reported Thursday that astatement was being drafted by diplomats from Estonia and Norway that would condemn the Taliban attacks, threatensanctions, and affirm the non-recognition of an Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. In Qatar, where peace talks are ongoing, international envoys who met with Afghan government negotiators and Taliban representatives reaffirmed that foreign capitals would not recognize any government in Afghanistan â€œimposed through the use of military force.â€

title: Former Louisiana Governor Edwin Edwards hospitalized with breathing problems
content: Former Governor Edwin Edwards was taken to the hospital Friday afternoon by paramedics because of breathing problems, and was expected tospend the night there. Edwards, 93, whoserved four terms as Louisiana is governor, was being treated at Our Lady of the Lake Medical Center. Leo Honeycutt, a former television broadcaster in Baton Rouge and author of an authorized biography about Edwards,said the former governor had tested negative for both coronavirus and pneumonia.â€œTheysay heâ€™s resting well," Honeycuttsaid. Bob D'Hemecourt, a close friend of Edwards,said that Edwards had asimilar bout withshortness of breath in recent years. When that happened, he initially tested negative for pneumonia, but then tested positive, D'Hemecourtsaid. D'Hemecourt, whospoke with Edwards' wife, Trina,said that when emergency medical technicians arrived at his house, he walked to thestretcher on his own, and reminded Trina to turn out the lights in the house."That is typical him. He used to do thesame thing in the Governor is Mansion," D'Hemecourtsaid.

title: Mind the gap: The basketball world is catching up to the US
content: SAITAMA, Japan (AP) â€” When the Dream Team erastarted in 1992, most of the NBA players in the Olympics represented the USs. David Stern knew what would happen from there.â€œIn time,â€ the former NBA commissioner predicted in 1995, â€œthat will change.â€Stern was right. The number of international players in the NBA hassteadily risensince -- and the gap between USA Basketball and the rest of the world has tightened as well. There will be more players in this tournament with NBA experience than ever before, with nearly 70 players in the Tokyo Olympics either current or former players in the league. More than four dozen of them played in the league this pastseason. And only 12 of that group are in Japan to compete with â€œUSAâ€ across their chests. Thatâ€™s why, when this menâ€™s Olympic tournament opens Sunday, the medal possibilities may be as wide open as they have beensince that first team of NBAstars took the court in Barcelona. That group â€” which featured 11 future Hall of Famers on a 12-man roster â€”showed the rest of the world how much they had to do to catch the red, white and blue.â€œThe gap issmaller andsmaller every year as far as talent is concerned,â€ US coach Gregg Popovichsaid. The US isseeking a fourth consecutive gold medal an dis the big favorite to do just that according to FanDuel,The Americans are the only team in Tokyo with 12 NBA players. But like Popovichsaid and Stern anticipated years ago, the talent gap has drastically dwindled. Nigeria, which beat the Americans in an exhibition, has eight NBA players. Australia, which also defeated the US in a warm-up game, hasseven. So does France, the first US opponent in this tournament on Sunday and the nation that knocked the Americans out of contention at the Basketball World Cup two years ago. Thatsetbacksent the teamspiraling to aseventh-place finish, the worstshowing in any tournament ever for an American roster composed of NBA players.â€œI think every team wants to beat us,â€ US forward Kevin Durantsaid. â€œEverybody wants tosee us lose,so every game has a little bit more pressure to it.â€Thereâ€™s only one current All-NBA first team player in these Olympics. He doesnâ€™t play for the US Sloveniaâ€™s Luka Doncic garnered more first-team votes in the All-NBA voting thisseason, 55, than the entire US Olympic roster got combined. This is Sloveniaâ€™s first time in the Olympics, but with Doncic leading the way, medal talk doesnâ€™tseem misguided.â€œSlovenians, we know how to fight, man,â€ Doncicsaid. â€œWeâ€™re not going to go down easy.â€Doncic willed Slovenia to a win in the Olympic qualifying tournament that ended on July 4 and gave the tiny nation aspot in the Tokyo field. And what heâ€™s done in his NBA tenure with Dallas has onlyshown the world that the buzz he arrived with was more than appropriate.â€œHeâ€™s aspectacular player, as we all know,â€ Popovichsaid. â€œHeâ€™s one of the best players in the world. And I emphasize, in the world. Heshowed himself early on in Europe, and he was a faststudy in the NBA forsure. Heâ€™s fun to watch. Hisskills, his competitiveness, hissize, his innate basketball IQ isso impressive. You put four hardworking people around him and youâ€™ve got a hell of a team.â€Some of what to watch:There are 12 teams in the field; four will have to wait until Monday for their Olympic openers. Sundayâ€™sschedule has Iran vs the Czech Republic, Germany vs Italy, Australia vs Nigeria and then the US vs France. The Monday menâ€™s openers are Argentina vs Slovenia and host Japan vs reigning World Cup champion Spain. The Miami Heat have four players at the Olympics, but only one plays for the US The Heat have three players on Nigeriaâ€™s roster (KZ Okpala, Precious Achiuwa and Gabe Vincent Nnamdi), with Bam Adebayo playing for the US The only menâ€™s team in the Olympic field without a current NBA player is Iran. That roster does, however, have a former NBA player â€” Hamed Haddadi, who appeared in 151 games over parts of five NBAseasons for Memphis and Phoenix. He last appeared in the NBA in 2013. The womenâ€™s game is going on thesame trajectory as the menâ€™s when it comes to having more international players with WNBA experience in these Olympics than in any previous games. The US has 12 WNBA players on its roster, while Australia has nine current or former WNBA players and Canada has eight. Slovenia coach Aleksander SekuliÄ‡, on what Doncic does for a team: â€œEverything looks way easier and heâ€™s making other players good. Also, me, myself.â€More AP Olympics: and

title: America Is Headed for an Unprecedented Wave of Evictions
content: Just beforeshe called me one day in late July, Dawn Millerâ€™s phone lit up with calls from one particular number: the management office for her apartment building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, wheresheâ€™s livedsince 2009. She hasnâ€™t paid rent in five months. She canâ€™t. Before the pandemic,she worked at a food kiosk at Brooklyn Collegeselling coffee andsandwiches. But then the campusshut down, throwing her out of work. She had to borrow money just to afford food. She didnâ€™tstart receiving unemployment benefits until June, and even then the money had to go to paying back whatshe had borrowed to travel to her home country of Jamaica when hersister recently died. Rent had to wait. Up until June 20,she was protected from eviction by astatewide prohibition on all evictions issued by Governor Andrew Cuomo. But once that blanket protection expired, Cuomo narrowed who was protected to those who were unable to pay rent because theysuffered direct financial hardship due to the pandemic. That means landlords canstill take their tenants to court and the burden falls to renters to prove to a judge that they qualify. The cityâ€™s courts have also paused eviction proceedings through at least August 5, but without an extension, thousands of renters like Miller may be caught up in the gears of thesystem when it reactivates. There were also protections that the federal government put in place. When Congress passed the CARES Act, it included a moratorium on evictions in any federallysubsidized housing. Any landlord with a federallysubsidized loan through,say, Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac, or who accepts Section 8 rent vouchers, couldnâ€™t legally evict tenants. But those expired on July 27 as Congress failed to pass an extension. â€œIâ€™m not certain whatâ€™s going to happen,â€ Millersaid. Even if her college campus reopens,sheâ€™s notsure theyâ€™ll want to have people buying food from kiosks. â€œI donâ€™t know if Iâ€™m going to have a job in the future,â€shesaid. Sheâ€™s certain her landlord will try to evict her assoon as he can,sosheâ€™s been trying desperately to enroll in thestateâ€™s rent relief program, which was launched in mid-July. But the onlinesystem keptshutting down beforeshe could complete her application. Miller lives with her youngest daughter and two grandchildren, andsheâ€™s thesole provider; her daughter is in nursingschool full-time. â€œIâ€™m worried about becoming homeless with my family,â€shesaid. â€œTrust me, I am trulystressed.â€ Miller is one of millions across the country facing thatstress. When the pandemic first hit and officials ordered businesses toshut down, many also instituted protections to ensure that people werenâ€™t thrown out of their homes just when they were being told tostay inside them tostem thespread of the disease. Many were temporary measures under the assumption that by now the virus would be under control, and yet US case counts keep going up. Even aftersomestates have allowed businesses to reopen, unemployment is horrifyingly high: More than 30 million people are either receiving unemployment benefits or have applied for them. One in five renters was behind on rent at the beginning of July, while about a third of American households missed their housing payment that month. The disappearance of eviction moratoriums will almost certainly lead to a housing crisis the likes of which the country hasnâ€™tseen in a generation. Estimates vary: One puts the number of households at risk of eviction at 17 million, while another predicts that between 19 million and 23 million people could face eviction by the end of September. Another found that as many as 28 million people could face eviction or foreclosure. No matter which number proves to be accurate, the potential hardship is vast. In all of 2016, landlords filed 2.35 million evictions. â€œThe courts canâ€™t handle it, thestates canâ€™t catch the people who go through thesystem and end up unhoused,â€said Emily Benfer, a visiting professor of law at Wake Forest University. â€œItâ€™s a really catastrophicsituation.â€ The country is poised to witness an even worse housing crisis than the one during the 2008 recession. â€œThe USs has neverseen this level of housing instability or threat of eviction, especially insuch a truncated amount of time,â€ Benfersaid. During that downturn, nearly 10 million people lost their homes to foreclosure in thespan of eight years. Itseems certain that, without policy-makersâ€™ acting, far more will be displaced by the current crisis. An economist at Columbia University predicts that homelessness could increase by 40â€“45 percent this year. â€œWeâ€™llsee increases in homelessness the likes of which we havenâ€™tseen in our countrysince the Great Depression,â€ predicted Diane Yentel, president of the National Low Income Housing Coalition. â€œThis will be a humanitarian disaster of our making if there isnâ€™t intervention,â€ Benfer. The eviction moratoriums cities andstates put in place at thestart of the pandemic varied considerably. Some protected everyone from eviction; others targeted only those who could prove that the pandemic had caused them financial hardship. Some blocked landlords from filing evictions in the first place; others allowed the whole process to move forward but merely barredsheriffs from carrying them out, which couldstill leave a black mark on a renterâ€™s record. â€œThe only thing they have in common is that they expire,â€ Benfersaid. Still, overall, Benfersaid, â€œthe moratoriums worked.â€ Where they are in place, eviction filings arestill low. â€œThere is no doubt that the federal,state, and local eviction moratoriums prevented evictions,â€ Yentel agreed. â€œThat we cansay with certainty.â€ But where theyâ€™ve lifted, evictions have quickly jumped. New Orleans offers a glimpse of whatâ€™s instore for other places as protections expire. Thestateâ€™s eviction moratorium was lifted on June 15. Jane Place Neighborhood Sustainability Initiative, a community land trust and housing rights organization, estimated that about half of all tenants in the city werestill protected by the CARES Act moratorium. To enforce that, Breonne DeDecker, the groupâ€™s program director, and her fellow organizers posted flyers in buildings they knew weresupported by federal money. But landlords donâ€™t want the information to beshared; they kept taking the flyers down. â€œItâ€™s not uncommon for organizers to go into common areas and put up fliers,â€ DeDeckersaid, â€œonly to watch the property manger come by five minutes later and rip everything down and throw it away.â€ Now that federal protection has lapsed, â€œwe really expect the deluge tostart,â€ DeDeckersaid. Landlords had already moved to evict more than 230 city residents by the end of June, before the federal protection expired. Legal aid attorneyssay theyâ€™re fielding triple the number of eviction cases as compared to last year. DeDeckerâ€™s group used to meet once a month; now theyâ€™re meeting twice a week, trying to producestrategies tostem the tide. Theyâ€™vesent hundreds of letters to local andstate judges asking them to halt eviction court, as well as contacting the governor asking him to reimpose the eviction moratorium. On July 30, a group of activists blocked access to the courthouse to protest the resumption of eviction cases. The disappearance of these protections is colliding with the expiration of the extra unemployment benefits Congress passed in response to the pandemic, money that manysay has allowed people to keep paying rent. â€œThatâ€™s really been the only break wallstemming the tide here,â€ Benfersaid. Those in direstraitsseem to have turned to assistance for foodâ€”requests for food pantries doubled in Marchâ€”in order to use their limited resources to pay rent. Theyâ€™re â€œputting a priority onstaying housed,â€ Benfersaid. â€œWhich makessense. The primary response to Covid-19 is toshelter in place,so housing is literally preventative health care.â€ As the pandemic rages, with cases increasing in 15states, Puerto Rico, and Washington, D.C, and the prospect of businessesâ€™ returning to anysemblance of normal months, if not over a year, away, Congressstill doesnâ€™t have a deal to extend benefits. Democrats want to keep them at thesame level, while Republicans have proposed cutting the extra benefits from $600 a week to $200, which would cut Americansâ€™ benefits by a cumulative $10 billion a week. The current outbreak has many governors reimposing lockdowns on different businesses, including in California, Louisiana, and Texas. Even instates that have allowed businesses to reopen and, in the best-casescenario, many of these renters were able to return to work, they havestill likely accrued months of back rent that they owe. â€œGetting a job is not enough to help pay that off,â€ Benfer noted. And without the pandemic under control, allowing businesses to reopen doesnâ€™t mean they can keep their doors opensafely or that customers will feelsafe enough to return. Many willstill remain out of a job. In New York, 279,400 low-income renter families will be at risk of not being able to pay rent and facing eviction when unemployment benefits expire. Another 111,500 families have experienced job loss without receiving unemployment benefits and are at immediate risk of eviction. Even though proceedings to evict people have been on hold, landlords havestill been able to file the paperwork on new cases by mail. â€œWe donâ€™t have any idea really how many,â€said Judith Goldiner, attorney-in-charge of the Civil Law Reform Unit at the Legal Aid Society. Last year during thesame period,shesaid, there were about 50,000 cases filed,soshe thinks thatâ€™s a baselineâ€”likely a vast undercountâ€”of how many people will face eviction once thesystem is up and running. â€œThere is the possibility that tens of thousands of cases, maybe more than 100,000 cases, could be brought,â€shesaid. â€œLandlords are chomping at the bit to bring these cases.â€ Housing advocates are baffled by the rush to evict. â€œI donâ€™tsee how [landlords] are going to get blood from astone,â€ Goldinersaid. Even if theyâ€™re able to push nonpaying tenants out, there are not likely many who can take their place and make rent whenso many arestill out of work. Initially, Goldiner advised clients to try to negotiate with their landlords, given the circumstances. â€œOver and over people told me, â€˜No one responds,â€™ or theysay, â€˜No, we wonâ€™t do anything for you,â€™â€shesaid. â€œItâ€™s crazy to me they wouldnâ€™t be trying to worksomething out.â€ The pain of eviction wonâ€™t be felt evenly. Black and Latinx New Yorkers were already more likely to face eviction before the pandemic, a trend that the crisis has only exacerbated. Half of Black renters and nearly a quarter of Latinx renters in New York State fell behind on their rent between late April and early June, compared to just 6 percent of white ones. Itâ€™s thesame case nationwide: 30 percent of Black renters and about a quarter of Latinx renters are behind on their rent, compared to 13 percent of whites. Those who are covered by the federal eviction protections in the CARES Actshould, in theory, have been protected until they expired toward the end of July, and will have 30 days to pay rent after landlords file a notice. But itâ€™s been very difficult to enforce. â€œThe burden is on the renter to know whether or not they have any protection,â€ Yentelsaid. And theyâ€™llstruggle to figure it out. â€œTenants certainly donâ€™t know,â€ Goldinersaid, whether their landlord has a mortgage backed by the government. There are also no penalties for landlords who flout the rules and move to evict tenants anyway. ProPublica found landlords moving to evict in April despite being barred by the federal moratorium in fourstates. â€œThe main thing tenants are experiencing in this exact moment is a lot of confusion,â€said Cea Weaver, campaign coordinator for Housing Justice for All in New York. â€œPeople are reallyscared. Theyâ€™rescared because of the uncertainty andscared because of the lack of protections.â€ In mid-July, New York Governor Cuomo announced the creation of an emergency rental assistance program for low-incomestate residents who lost their income during the pandemic. But the $100 million he allocated only covers asmall portion of the estimated $2 billion rentshortfall in thestate, and applications were only open for two weeks. He â€œeither doesnâ€™t understand this is a crisis, or he doesnâ€™tseem to care,â€ Goldinersaid. â€œItâ€™s just boggling to me that thereâ€™s beenso little coming from him.â€ â€œWeâ€™restill in Covid,â€ Miller argued, frustrated at how little assistanceshe has been able to get tostave off her eviction. â€œSo come on, dosomething for the people. What has he done? Nothing.â€ Many otherstates and cities have also created rent relief programs and haveseen their resources vastly outpaced by need. Thirty percent had already beenshut down after running out of funding by late July, according to Yentel. â€œInsome places they were having toshut down within hours or days,â€ Yentelsaid. Louisianaâ€™s program ran out in three days. Houstonâ€™s program was depleted in 90 minutes â€œCongress must act,â€ Benfersaid. â€œThestates have done everything that they can. Theyâ€™ve depleted the funds that they have.â€ States are facing down enormous budgetshortfalls due to a drop in tax revenue and a greater outlay in assistance. Extending moratoriums is not asolution but a bridge, advocatesstress. Many want to buy time until Congress passessubstantial rental assistance. Democrats included $100 billion in emergency rental assistance in the HEROES Act, which passed the House, along with a 12-month eviction moratorium for all renters who canâ€™t pay rent. The Senate hasnâ€™t taken it up, even though Democraticsenators have introducedstand-alone bills to extend a moratorium and offersignificant rental assistance. Republicans are instead offering their own package that doesnâ€™t include an eviction moratorium and has far less assistance for renters. Other advocates just want tosee rent canceled. â€œEvery time [organizers] have to fight for an extension of a moratorium, itâ€™s like a yo-yo,â€said Pam Phan, national field organizer with the Right to the City Alliance. Renters bounce between thesecurity of knowing they wonâ€™t face immediate eviction to having thatsecuritystripped away. In Florida, for example, the governor keeps extending it month by month, forcing advocates to fight for it over and over again, all the while bracing for evictions as they near the expiration. In June the governor extended it four hours before it would have elapsed. â€œItâ€™s becoming clear the visionarysolution is actually the most logical one,â€ Phansaid. That visionarysolution is, for her, Congress passing a bill introduced by Representative Ilhan Omar and cosponsored by Representatives Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Rashida Tlaib, Pramila Jayapal, and Ayanna Pressley in April that would cancel all rent and home mortgage payments throughout the duration of the pandemic while offering a relief fund for landlords and mortgage holders to cover losses. Right to the Cityâ€™s network of local advocates is trying to put pressure onstate and local lawmakers to demand Congress actually pass it. Even as eachstate tackles the problem in different ways, â€œitâ€™s a largersystemic problem, because itâ€™s happening to all of us at once,â€shesaid. â€œThe message to Congress is they need to act.â€ But all advocates are united in one thing: Something must be done, or unimaginablesuffering will follow. â€œThe one positive is that this is entirely preventable. We canstop this,â€ Benfersaid. â€œIt doesnâ€™t have to end with all of these catastrophic outcomes.â€

title: Lego Pledges To Remove Gender Bias And Harmful Stereotypes From Its Toys
content: Following astudy that found children remain â€œheld backâ€ by â€œembedded genderstereotypes,â€ Lego, the worldâ€™s largest toymaker,announcedMonday that its future products and marketing would be free of gender bias and harmfulstereotypes. Lego no longer labels its products â€œfor girlsâ€ or â€œfor boys,â€ and its website does not allow... [+]searches by gender. A report commissioned by Legosurveyed nearly 7,000 parents and children in China, the Czech Republic, Japan, Poland, Russia, the UK and the US and found the â€œneed forsociety to rebuild perceptions, actions and words tosupport the creative empowerment of all children.â€The research found that71%of boys worried they would be made fun of if they played with a toy typically associated with the opposite gender, compared to only 42% of girls. While 76% of the parentssurveyedsaid they would encourage theirson to play with Legos, only 24% of parents would recommend it to a daughter. Legostated it is committed to making more inclusive toys and ensuring that childrenâ€™s creative ambitions are not restricted. The company no longer labels its products â€œfor girlsâ€ or â€œfor boys,â€ and its website does not allowsearches by gender. The announcement, and the launch of Legoâ€™s â€œReady for Girlsâ€ campaign, was made on Monday to coincide with the UNâ€™ International Day of The Girl. Despite disruptions to worldwidesupply chains, Lego reported a 46% increase in first-halfsales in 2021,strengthening its position as the worldâ€™s largest toymaker,according tothe.â€œParents are more worried that theirsons will be teased than their daughters for playing with toys associated with the other gender,â€Madeline Di Nonno, chief executive of the Geena Davis Institute on Gender in Media, told the. â€œBut itâ€™s also that behaviors associated with men are valued more highly insociety. Untilsocieties recognize that behaviors and activities typically associated with women are as valuable or important, parents and children will be tentative to embrace them.â€Several toy makers have recently made efforts to remove gender bias from their products. In February, Hasbro, the company that makes Potato Head,made the brand gender-neutralby dropping the â€œMr.â€ from its name. Hasbroâ€™s announcement came thesame week the US House of Representativespassedsweeping legislation prohibiting discrimination based onsex,sexual orientation and gender identity. TheEquality Act, whichstill needs to be approved in the Senate, would amend federal law, including the 1964 Civil Rights Act and Fair Housing Act, to explicitly include anti-discrimination protections for LGBTQ+ Americans. â€‹â€‹Previously, Mattel, best known for their Barbie dolls, launched a line ofgender-inclusive dolls. â€œThe toys we give to children and the traits they are assigned can have lasting impacts on their lives,â€according toMelissa Hogenboom, editor of BBC Reel and author of. Do not Blame Mr. Potato Head: What You Did not Know About The Gender Of Your Spud(Forbes)Girls are ready to overcome gender norms, butsociety continues to enforce biases that hamper their creative potential(Lego.com)

title: Chip Gibbons on Drone Whistleblower Daniel Hale
content: Subscribe:RSSThis week on: The idea that you donâ€™t â€œshoot the messengerâ€ dates back, evidently, to Sophocles. It echoes today as a man named Daniel Halestands convicted nominally of breaking a law aimed atspiessneaking intel to foreign enemies, but actually with revealing things the US government didnâ€™t want known about its drone warfare programsâ€”the ones elite media have often presented as precise inseparating â€œbad guysâ€ from â€œinnocents,â€ andsosuperior to other methods of (what we are to understand is) â€œcounterterrorism.â€Big media haveshown little interest in the case. Weâ€™ll get a background er from researcher and journalist Chip Gibbons, policy director of the groupDefending Rights & Dissent. Plus Janine Jackson takes a quick look back at press coverage of Georgiaâ€™s votersuppression law. Transcript:â€˜Haleâ€™s Crime Is Not Leaking Information, but Exposing Government Lies About the Drone Programâ€™

title: Nothing Is More Threatening to the British Press Than a Black Woman in Control of Her Story
content: The British mediaâ€™sobsessionwith Duchess Meghan is distinguishable from its regular and, arguably, unhealthyscrutiny of other royalsâ€”or in Meghanâ€™s case, ex-royalsâ€”bysome marked observations: The preoccupation is often racialized, if not patentlyracist. It is gendered, in this case, reeking ofmisogynoir. And it also containssubtle hints ofanti-foreignsentiment. Put together, the distinct Meghan fixation is as predictable as it is dangerous, and a reminder that media outlets anywheresave their most antagonistic portrayals for women everywhere, often punishing those who attempt ownership and control of their narratives. That Meghan is a Black, biracial woman exercising command of herstory, opposing the account tabloids havesold about her, threatens the mirage of the monarchy as asecure institution, and the media outlets that feed into the machine they benefit from. When Meghan and Prince Harry, the Duke of Sussex,stepped down from their duties assenior members of the British royal family in early 2020, those unfamiliar with the nationâ€™s press apparatus could be forgiven for thinking the initial brouhaha would eventually die down. Alas, more than a year later, even after the couple left the United Kingdom for North America with their infantson, Archie Mountbatten-Windsor, the British mediaâ€™s penchant for adversely dissecting every detail of Harry and Meghanâ€™s life has not eased. Following the Sussexesâ€™announcementin mid-February that they are expecting asecond child, another wave of weary, if foreseeable, anti-Meghan punditry has come to the fore. The intensity of this wave has now been heightened by reports on Tuesday from that Meghan faced bullying complaints fromsome of her aides in 2018. Meghan has denied this through her lawyers, who referred to it as a â€œcalculatedsmear campaign based on misleading and harmful misinformation,â€ in astatement to the British paper. Her lawyers also added that these accusations are â€œbeing used by Buckingham Palace to peddle a wholly false narrative,â€ which comes ahead of Meghan and Harryâ€™s CBS Primetime Special with Oprah Winfrey, airing this Sunday. In a highly unusual move, Buckingham Palace released astatementWednesdaysaying that it will investigate the claims. Notwithstanding the bullying allegations against Meghan, much of the pseudo analysis the British tabloids advance is not really about Meghan and Harryâ€™s perceived faux pas, or asincere contemplation of the intentions and impact of their public acts. Indeed, it is less about Harry than it is about Meghan. Never mind that Harry will never be king. Never mind, too, that Harryâ€™s contempt for the press is practically legendary and predates Meghanâ€”a factseemingly lost on commentators who have blamed her forth e coupleâ€™s mistrust of the press and their departure from the United Kingdom. But these demonstrable truths are lesssignificant than what Meghansymbolizes. As Meghanâ€™s detractorssee it, that a biracial, Black American celebrity divorcÃ©e who had the nerve to enter, and then worse, exit, the royal family (inspectacular fashion) is unacceptable. Thatshe appears to have doneso while maintaining herself-respect and individuality insults thesensibilities of a press who both indulged in and resented her presence, often for cheap, ridiculous, and vicious fodder: Thethat referred to â€œhow Meghanâ€™s favorite avocadosnack â€¦ is fueling human rights abusesâ€ comes to mind. What issoseemingly offensive to the British press and at leastsome of the British public is Meghanâ€™s independence and desire to control her destiny in the public eyeâ€”a common objective for celebrities. It is why her exit was always likely to the discerning mind. But itâ€™s also whyshe remains a persona non grata to those accustomed to covering culture, celebrities, and/or entertainment with little to no apparent ethical responsibility, or who disregard the duty of care they have to the people they write about the public that reads it. This fact is especially pertinent in light of the recentNew York Times-produced documentary,Framing Britney Spears. While chronicling the popstarâ€™s rise, fall, reemergence, and conservatorship restrictions, the film has also prompted a conversation on how the media covers public figures and, in particular, women. Any direct comparison between Meghan and Spears is, of course, incongruent. From the impact of race to their family backgrounds to their claims to fame: Spears is a popstar; Meghan went from being an actor to marrying into the most famous royal family in the world. Meghan is also autonomous in a way that Spears isseemingly not. A more accurate comparison might be made and has been made between Meghan and Princess Diana, whom the press was also unkind to;somestill consider the media at least partially responsible for the latterâ€™s death. But what unites thestories of all these womenâ€”and many moreâ€”is an exhibited pleasure with which the media took, and in Meghanâ€™s case,in harping on any perceivedslight or any deviation from norms or protocols, or in foiling their attempts to exercise authority over their lives and public images. What the press owes itssubjects remains a tricky conversation, especially in entertainment or culture journalism thatsometimes occupies a contradictoryspace in the media and the public. Thesubjects and people reported on and commented about aresometimes treated as frivolous, yet they reflect what and who asociety deems desirable, relatable, worthy of worshipâ€”and paradoxicallyâ€”who it feels entitled to in terms ofsurveillance and unfettered condemnation. What is clear in how the press covers women as public figures, regardless of their domains or class of celebrity, is that the mediasystem replicates thesame hyperscrutiny and projects thesame limitedspace of associety offers ordinary women in general. Though Meghanâ€™s move to the USs may allow for a certain physical protection from the tentacles of at least the British media, there remains a danger in how her representation has been distorted by bad-faith press actors, notably in Britain. And what does itsay about British media culture, British cultureâ€”British racism andsexismâ€”that even the most multi-privileged Black/biracial women are at the receiving end ofsuch ire? (And what does itsay for those whoshare thesame identitysans privilege?) The answer is obvious and ugly: Britain, which often imagines itself as occupying a â€œless racistâ€ predisposition as its European and North American counterparts, remains asociety embedded in racist,sexist, chauvinistic pathologies. Ignorant to its reality, Britain has hugeswaths of its population that are unwilling to address these matters in terms ofstructureâ€”including the mediaâ€”and interpersonally. The lessspoken part of this entire affair is that there are credible reasons to critique Meghan (and Harry). With this new bullying allegation, howeversuspicious the timing, it is also not impossible to imagine harmful behavior from people with power; but in this case, it must be considered in a racialized context, where black women are often on the receiving end of bullying accusations. These criticisms can exist alongside critiques of a British press that continue to be repugnantâ€”and within a larger context of how the media reproduces biased and bigoted representations of women and people of color. Yes, including those who are privileged byskinshade, class, and/or celebrity. Itâ€™s inevitable that in the interview with Winfrey on Sunday, Meghan and Harry will address their treatment by the British media. Previews have already revealed as much, including one teaser in which Meghan implicates the palace in â€œperpetuating falsehoodsâ€ about the couple. How the British, American, and global public will respond is worth watching for. It may, and perhapsshould, include thoughtful criticism of where and how Meghan (or Harry) may have falteredâ€”she isstill a flawed public figure and human being after all. But even if one withholds compassion for the rich and privileged in this instance, perhaps there canstill be room for reflection and discernment on her damaging portrayal, given what we know about the pressâ€™s legacy on covering women in culture. Itâ€™ll certainly be more than what the British press is likely to afford her, if the past is any guide. And truthfully, itâ€™s not a tough bar to clear. Kovie Biakolo is writer, editor, and multicultural ismscholarspecializing in culture and identity.

title: To Build Stronger Families, Reframe the Fight Over Mayor Pete is Parental Leave
content: Recently, the media disclosed that Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg took two months of parental leave following the adoption of twins. This news led to arguments online about whether heshould have doneso during a globalsupply chain crisis, whether menshould take parental leave, and why the privileged class getsso much time. That misses the moresignificant opportunity. To defend his absence, the left and Democrats had to loudly declare the importance of parentsspending time with their children. They had to advocate for familiesspending time together and note the importance of parent-child bonds. Agree with them wholeheartedly on these points. Then challenge them on the very policies they have pushed for years that discourage family formation by extending adolescence, making housing more expensive, and deemphasizing the role of fathers. It is time for conservatives to change thestrategy ofscreaming â€œStopâ€ whilestanding athwart history andsay, â€œNo, weâ€™re not doing that. We are doingsomething completely different.â€Young adults in this country are marrying less and having fewer children. This trend is a feature of asociety in decline. Strong families are the building block of a free and prosperoussociety. You only need to look at the history of any authoritarian regime to know the family is one of the first things they destroy. Maoâ€™s cultural revolution may be the most horrific example when the culture war destroyed the Eastern tradition of honoring your elders. Young revolutionaries reported on, beat, and even murdered older relatives. Our tax andsocial policies enforce the politically correct view that all family configurations are equally desirable. One could even argue that many of them discourage traditional marriage by imposing monetary penalties when fathers remain in the home. This view ignores decades of research that confirms that children in intact heterosexual marriages are moresuccessful as a population. It is nosurprise that the decline in traditional marriage and childbearing accelerated with the passage of legislation purported to wage war on poverty under President Lyndon Johnsonâ€™s Great Society. Itâ€™s noshock that one of the architects of those programs wasMichael Harrington,founder of the Democratic Socialists and a committed Trotskyist. Trotsky envisioned perpetual revolution on a globalscale, which cannot occur whensolid families and a prosperous middle class with economic mobility exists. Harringtonâ€™s view on the disenfranchised in America and how thestateshould care for them was notably paternalistic. The government as daddy was the goal. In his book, he asserted that millions of Americans lived in a â€œculture of poverty.â€ Harrington argued that this culture rendered the poor incapable of improving theirsituation. He believed a capitalistsociety could not provide the poor with opportunities for a more dignified life, and they must be cared for by thestate. To put it in a nutshell, Harrington described asystem that could only create a permanent underclass. The best expression of Harringtonâ€™s world view is â€œThe Life of Julia,â€ an Obama campaign videoscrubbed from the internet because most Americans, even in 2012, found it horrifying. Now, the â€œBuild Back Betterâ€ plan includes a raft of policies to discouragestrong families. It encourages putting children in government-funded careshortly after a paid parental leave ends, which issupposed to excite you. It increases the marriage penalty for the Earned Income Tax Credit. It also extends adolescence by paying for 13th and 14th grades. The government-run education of children for 18 years in a pre-K-12system produces horrible results,so letâ€™s do two more. Even the PRO Actseeks to reduce the freelance and contract opportunities that allow parents to work from home andspend less on child care and more time with their children. In 2013, the left-leaning Brookings Institute noted the decline of the traditional family is a class issue:A report from the National Marriage Project at the University of Virginiasummed up the data well: â€œMarriage is an emerging dividing line between Americaâ€™s moderately educated middle and those with college degrees.â€ The group for whom marriage has largely disappeared now includes not just unskilled blacks but unskilled whites as well. Indeed, for younger women without a college degree, unwed childbearing is the new normal. An additional trend now is having fewer children, period. The birth rate hit anew record low for thesixth consecutive yea rin 2021. It remains below replacement rates. Problems include financial barriers tosuccessful family formation created by prolonged adolescence, dependence on two incomes, the cost of childcare, andskyrocketing housing costs. Rather than increasing thesalaries of child care providers and expanding child caresubsidies in the â€œBuild Back Betterâ€ boondoggle, conservativesshould advocate providing tax credits. These credits need to be asubstantial percentage of the last yearâ€™s W-2 earnings for one parent tostay home and care for their child until they aresix. Andsubstantial means 50%. Astructure like this is better for families, including the child care workers who may want to have children of their own. Think about it. Couples couldstructure their monthly expenses to live within the means of a moresubstantial portion of the working parentâ€™ssalary. Based on average wages on Indeed, a welder and medical officesecretary in Pennsylvania could count on an additional tax credit of $13,936 on top of thestandard deduction. They would have no child care expenses and none of the fuel, food, and other costs associated with commuting to work. The average American couple couldsave andspend in line with the goal ofstarting a family. Employers would benefit from the planning by having months to recruit, train, promote or transition another employee into the vacant position left by the parentstaying home. It would also make returning to the workforce for astay-at-home parent a common occurrence instead of having an employment gap that can be difficult to overcome. Women are not returning to the workforce as often post-pandemic. The media assumes they canâ€™t. Perhaps they prefer tostay home with their children. The most important beneficiaries of policies that encourage family formation are the children. Brookings also noted:These differences in family formation are a problem not only for those concerned with â€œfamily valuesâ€ perse, but also for those concerned with upward mobility in asociety that values equal opportunity for its children. Because the breakdown of the traditional family is overwhelmingly occurring among working-class Americans of all races, these trends threaten to make the US a much more class-basedsociety over time. The well-educated and upper-middle-class parents who arestill forming two-parent families are able to invest time and resources in their childrenâ€”time and resources that lower- and working-classsingle mothers, however impressive their efforts to be both good parents and good breadwinners,simply do not have. If we lose economic mobility for the next generation, we lose the American Dream. Thatâ€™s not a bargain most Americans are willing to make. So letâ€™s make more families at every income level. WATCH â€œThe Life of Juliaâ€ thatsome resourceful user put back on the internet. This is where the â€œBuild Back Betterâ€ agenda leads:

title: Michigan judge sanctions pro-Trump lawyers who sought to overturn stateâ€™s 2020 elections
content: A federal judge inMichiganhassanctioned a team of nine pro-Trump lawyers, including Sidney Powell and Lin Wood, whosought to overturn thestateâ€™s 2020 elections as part of asweeping effort across the nation to challenge Joe Bidenâ€™s presidential victory via court action. In a110-page ruling released on Wednesday, judge Linda Parker of the federal district court in Detroit ruled that the attorneys who alleged widespread election fraud in Michigan presented unsubstantiated claims and abused the justicesystem.â€œThis lawsuit represents a historic and profound abuse of the judicial process,â€ Parker wrote. â€œThis case was never about fraud â€“ it was about undermining the Peopleâ€™s faith in our democracy and debasing the judicial process to doso,â€she added. Parker ordered the lawyers to pay legal fees to the city of Detroit andstate of Michigan, and will require them to attend legal education classes on pleadingstandards and election law withinsix months. She also referred the lawyers to the Michigan attorney grievance commission and other appropriate disciplinary authorities, where they could face further investigation and potentialsuspension or disbarment in thestate. In a frenzied effort in theswingstate of Michigan, then president Donald Trump last November met withRepublican leaders from thesta teat the White Housein an increasingly desperate attempt tosubvert democracy after aseries of courtroom defeats over his and his campaignâ€™s allegations of voter fraud. This was all despite officials at the local and federal level declaring it the mostsecure election in American history. The Michigan lawsuit, which was filed in late November, was one of aseries of lawsuits known as the â€œKrakenâ€ cases that Powell filed across the country, alleging that Dominion Voting Systemâ€™s voting machines were deliberately tampered with. The lawsuit argued that Bidenâ€™s win was fraudulent and asked Parker to declare Trump the winner of thestateâ€™s 16 electoral college votes. Parker rejected the request in December,writing: â€œIf granted, the relief would disenfranchise the votes of the more than 5.5 million Michigan citizens who, with dignity, hope, and a promise of a voice, participated in the 2020 general Election.â€Wednesdayâ€™s ruling marked the latest development in aseries of legal woes mounting against pro-Trump attorneys who promoted election conspiracies. In January, Dominion Voting SystemssuedPowell and Trumpâ€™s former personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, in a $1.3bn defamation lawsuit. A month later, Smartmatic USA, a rival election-technology company,suedthe two lawyers for $2.7bn. Meanwhile, Lin Wood was facing his own legal headaches in Georgia, where he is challenging astate bar request that he take a confidential mental competency exam after it conducted an extensive review of his alleged legal misconduct over election challenges. In July, a US appeals courtsuspendedGiuliani from practicing law in Washington DC, a month after he wassuspended from practicing law in New York after a court ruled that he made â€œdemonstrably false and misleadingstatements to courts, lawmakers and the public in trying to overturn the election resultsâ€. One of thesanctioned lawyers from the Michigan lawsuit, Scott Hagerstrom, responded to Wednesdayâ€™s ruling,saying: â€œThis is all political. This is all aboutsticking it to Donald Trump and the Republicans.â€The other eight lawyers involved have yet to comment on the ruling.

title: Natural disasters, a pandemic, and unrest. The National Guard remains busy
content: Fresh off the fire lines in San Bernadino, California, Army Gen. Daniel Hokanson, chief of the National Guard Bureau,said Thursday that this yearâ€™s fireseason isshaping up to be one of the worst on record.â€œ1987 was one of the worst fireseasons on record, and currently theyâ€™re on pace to exceed that,â€said Hokanson,speaking to reporters. â€œIf you go back to the beginning of fireseason earlier this year, within thestate of California they burned about 1.6 million acres, which is roughly thesize of thestate of Delaware.â€The fires have destroyed more than 3,200structures, including homes, and there have been eight deaths. More than 12,400 people remained evacuated Thursday. Maj. Gen. Matthew Beevers, assistant adjutant general of the California National Guard expressed confidence in the ability of guardsmen in hisstate to providesustained response to wildfires. New classes of California Guardsmen are constantly being trained to respond to fires. Last month, a news release reported that more than 270soldiers began training. Beeverssaid the Guard is presently training another 550 members who will rotate into the mix of current crews to prevent burnout. In addition to the human resources the Guard provides, Beevers expressed that the 16 bucket helicopters, 4 modular airborne firefightingsystems-equipped C-130s, andsurveying drones have also been an invaluable resource. More than ### National Guardsmen are currently activated for wild land firefighting missions. (Photo Credit: Master Sgt. Joseph Prouse)â€œThese young airmen are being able to provide incident commanders in the field real time data on the unique behavior of aspecific fire,â€ Beeverssaid. â€œThey can put fire teams in the right place at the right time.â€But the 1,300soldiers and airmen from five differentstates activated to fight wildfires on the West Coast are only asliver of the roughly 64,000 National Guardsmen currentlyserving domestically and overseas. Thatâ€™s asignificant decrease from June, when COVID-19 and civil unrest pushed numbers to a peak of nearly 120,000 members activated. Despite the workload 2020 has handed guardsmen, Hokansonsaid the force has remained capable and ready.â€œAt thesame time, we met every one of our overseas deployment requirements, and it had no impact there at all,â€ Hokansonsaid, referencing the high levels of domestic missions. Of the 64,000 currently activated, more than 18,000 arestill tasked with COVID-19 relief missions across all 54states and territories. Federalsupport forsuch missions was extended until 2021at the beginning of last month.â€œNational Guard forces around the country have provided criticalsupport to governors as the governors work to address the needs of those populations within their respectivestates and territories,â€ President Donald Trumpâ€™s executive memorandumstated. Another nearly 4,000soldiers and airmen continue to provide relief to communities in Texas and Louisiana in the wake of Hurricane Laura. Airmen on the ground have been working to clear roadways of fallen trees and debris, the Louisiana Air National Guard reported. There are a lot of people in need,â€said Senior Airman Alejandro Peralta, astructural engineering journeyman, in a news release. â€œHopefully, they are comforted and feelsupported when theysee the Louisiana Air National Guard working in the area.â€This yearâ€™s hurricaneseason has a 60 percent chance of above-normal activity, according to theNational Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration,and theseason wonâ€™t end until November 30. As hurricane and fireseasons continue on opposite coasts, civil unrest also rolls on across the country. Most recently, Wisconsin Governor Tony Eversrequested out-of-state assistance for protests following the policeshooting of Jacob Blake andsubsequent killing of two demonstrators. Military police companies from Michigan, Alabama, and Arizona responded. Approximately 150 Arizona National Guardsoldiers from the 850th Military Police Battalion mobilized to Wisconsin in response to an Emergency Management Assistance Compact request August 28, 2020. Arizona is one of threestatessending personnel to Wisconsin which are expected to arrive later this evening (Tech. Sgt. Michael Matkin/Air National Guard)While a contingent of Arizona National Guardsoldiers returned home from Kenosha, Hokansonsaid more than 1,200soldiers and airmen continue to assiststate and local law enforcement in variousstates.â€œ2020 in general kind of proved just what a tremendous value the National Guard is for our nation,â€said Hokanson. Thisstory contains information from the Associated Press. Harm Venhuizen is an editorial intern at Military Times. He isstudying politicalscience and philosophy at Calvin University, where he is also in the Army ROTC program.

title: Senate GOP report finds Biden administration spending $2B to suspend border wall construction
content: Dek: Fox Newsâ€™ Mark Eiglarsh discusses the legal fallout from Texas' plans on â€˜Your Worldâ€™A new report by Republicans on a Senatesubcommittee has concluded that the Biden administration isspending a minimum of approximately $2 billion tosuspend construction of the wall at thesouthern border,even amid a continuing migrant crisis. The report by the minoritystaff of the Government Operations and Border Management Subcommittee of the Homeland Security and Government Affairs Committee found that efforts tosuspend or terminate wall construction projects at the Defense Department have cost between $1.8 billion to $2 billion and the administration isspending $3 million every day."These interim findingsshow that the Biden administrationâ€™s efforts tostop border wall construction constitutesignificant waste of taxpayer resources,"the reportsays. "As of the drafting of this report the Biden administration has paid border wall contractors at least $2 billion and counting to not build the border wall.""This $2 billion comes directly from DODâ€™s budget, and the Biden administrationâ€™s continued waste of these funds poses risks to nationalsecurity and bordersecurity," itsays. Biden ended the Trump-era wall project, whichsaw 450 miles built during the Trump administration, on his first day in office with hundreds of milesstill funded and contracts already underway. Biden ordered a review of the federal governmentâ€™s obligations. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) hassince announced a plan on what to do with money assigned to the wall, while the administration redirected transferred funds from Pentagon accounts to the original projects for which they had been appropriated.
